questions.text: A 6-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician because he has become increasingly irritable and restless over the past 2 days. During this period, he has had 12 bowel movements. He feeds 10 to 12 times a day. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation and weighed 1800 g (3 lb 15 oz); he currently weighs 1700 g (3 lb 12 oz). His mother has Graves disease and received propylthiouracil during the last trimester of pregnancy. She has a history of intravenous heroin use. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 180/min, and respirations are 50/min. Examination shows mild diaphoresis and a firm 2-cm midline neck swelling. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Up to 5% of infants born to mothers with Graves disease develop thyrotoxicosis due to the transplacental passage of maternal stimulatory TSH receptor antibodies (TRAb). Symptoms may appear directly after birth or can be delayed up to 10 days as a result of transplacental maternal antithyroid medication (e.g., propylthiouracil, carbimazole). The thyrotoxicosis is transient and usually resolves within 12 weeks, when the maternal TRAb disappears from the infant's circulation. Before resolution, though, neonatal thyrotoxicosis should be treated as soon as it is diagnosed to prevent complications such as cardiac failure, intellectual disability, and craniosynostosis. Methimazole is administered to achieve a euthyroid state, which can take up to a few weeks. During this period, a beta blocker (e.g., propranolol) should be coadministered to rapidly control the thyrotoxic symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Potassium iodide is preferred as an adjunctive treatment of thyrotoxicosis refractory to treatment with antithyroid drugs and beta blockers. Its therapeutic benefit is limited because the thyroid gland overcomes the iodide block within a few weeks.

C) INCORRECT:

Naloxone is an opioid antagonist which is used in the management of opioid toxicity. Given that this mother has a history of IV heroin use, this newborn may have been exposed in-utero, which would put him at risk of developing drug withdrawal symptoms (neonatal abstinence syndrome or NAS). Although patients with NAS due to heroin can present with irritability and restlessness, they mostly become symptomatic within 1–3 days after birth due to the short half-life of heroin. Other common symptoms of NAS are also not present, such as a high-pitched cry, feeding difficulties, vomiting, and refusal to sleep and to be consoled. Moreover, naloxone is not used in the treatment of NAS. NAS due to heroin withdrawal is treated with opioid therapy (e.g., morphine, methadone) with gradual tapering and discontinuation.

D) INCORRECT:

Dextrose therapy is indicated in the management of neonatal hypoglycemia. The neonate in this vignette is at risk of developing hypoglycemia because of his low birth weight and diarrhea. Although irritability, diaphoresis, and tachycardia are important symptoms of hypoglycemia, the frequent feeds, and goiter cannot be explained by hypoglycemia. In contrast, a hypoglycemic infant will be listless, hypotonic, have a shrill cry, and feed poorly (due to fatigue).

E) INCORRECT:

Empirical administration of ampicillin and gentamicin may be indicated for neonatal sepsis. Although sepsis in a neonate can manifest as irritability, tachycardia, and tachypnea, it does not cause goiter. A neonate with sepsis would also have poor feeding and hypo/hyperthermia. Additionally, this neonate has no risk factors for the development of neonatal sepsis, such as prolonged rupture of membranes, prematurity, maternal chorioamnionitis.

F) INCORRECT:

Calcium gluconate therapy is indicated in the management of neonatal hypocalcemia, which is commonly asymptomatic but can also manifest with muscle twitches/jerks or seizures. Risk factors for the development of neonatal hypocalcemia include maternal diabetes/hyperparathyroidism and prematurity (for early-onset hypocalcemia, < 2 days after birth) and cow's milk/high-phosphate formula feeds (for late-onset hypocalcemia, > 3 days after birth). Late-onset hypocalcemia is very rare. In this neonate, the presence of a goiter and a maternal history of Graves' disease make the diagnosis of hypocalcemia unlikely.
questions.hint: This neonate, born to a mother with Graves disease, has features highly suggestive of neonatal thyrotoxicosis: irritability, restlessness, tachycardia, goiter, diaphoresis, increased bowel movement, and poor weight gain despite an adequate appetite.

questions.text: A 3-week-old male newborn is brought to the hospital because of poor weight gain since birth. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation via normal vaginal delivery. He weighed 3005 g (6 lb, 10 oz) at birth and currently weighs 2835 g (6 lb, 4 oz). He has been latching on and breastfeeding well since birth. His mother has a history of Graves disease and underwent near-total thyroidectomy in the second trimester of her pregnancy after her symptoms could not be controlled with antithyroid drugs. She is currently receiving L-thyroxine therapy. The patient's temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 176/min, and respirations are 42/min. He appears irritable. Examination shows a diaphoretic infant with a paucity of subcutaneous fat. There is swelling of the neck at the midline. Which of the following is the most likely cause?

choices.text: Activating mutation of the TSH receptor gene
Transplacental passage of thyroid peroxidase antibodies
Transplacental passage of TSH receptor antibodies

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thyroglobulin antibodies (TgAbs) are found in approx. 50–70% of patients with Graves disease and > 80% of patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis. Although this patient's mother has a history of Graves disease and the antibodies can pass the placenta, TgAbs are not thought to be involved in the pathogenesis of hyperthyroidism in Graves disease. Rather, they are believed to be a response to rapid cell destruction/disordered growth and subsequent release of circulating free thyroglobulin into the bloodstream. They are therefore not likely to be the cause of this infant's symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

An activating mutation (or gain-of-function mutation) of the TSH receptor gene is the underlying pathophysiology of toxic adenoma. Since toxic adenomas produce large amounts of thyroid hormones, independent of normal hypothalamic-pituitary feedback regulation, they also cause hyperthyroidism. However, the condition is most common in adults between 30–50 years of age and would be unlikely in a neonate.

C) INCORRECT:

Thyroid peroxidase antibodies (TPOAbs) are present in ∼ 70% of patients with Graves disease and > 90% of patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis. Although this patient's mother has a history of Graves disease and the antibodies can pass the placenta, TPOAbs are not known to be involved in the pathogenesis of hyperthyroidism in Graves disease, but rather result from the autoimmune nature of the condition. They are therefore not likely to be the cause of this infant's symptoms.

D) CORRECT:

Up to 5% of infants born to mothers with Graves disease develop thyrotoxicosis due to the transplacental passage of maternal stimulatory TSH-receptor antibodies (TRAbs). TRAbs are present in ∼ 90% of patients with Graves disease and cause increased growth and function of the thyroid gland and the subsequent development of hyperthyroidism and goiter. Neonatal thyrotoxicosis is transient and usually resolves within 12 weeks, when maternal TRAbs disappear from the infant's circulation. Although the condition is transient, symptomatic neonatal thyrotoxicosis should be treated as soon as it is diagnosed to prevent complications such as cardiac failure, intellectual disability, and craniosynostosis. Therapy consists of methimazole to achieve a euthyroid state and a beta blocker (e.g., propranolol) to rapidly control the thyrotoxic symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Although L-thyroxine has a long half-life (6–7 days), L-thyroxine only minimally crosses the placenta and is considered a category A drug during pregnancy, i.e., controlled human studies showed no risk for the fetus. It would therefore be an unlikely cause of this patient's symptoms.
questions.hint: This neonate has features highly suggestive of neonatal thyrotoxicosis: irritability, tachycardia, goiter, diaphoresis, and poor weight gain since birth despite an adequate appetite. The mother's history of Graves disease provides a clue for the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intermittent episodes of heart palpitations for 3 weeks. The palpitations are accompanied by chest pain that is sharp and localized to the left 3rd intercostal space. The patient does not smoke. She drinks one to two glasses of wine on the weekends. She appears nervous. Her pulse is 110/min and irregularly irregular, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Examination shows a fine tremor on both hands and digital swelling. There is retraction of the left upper eyelid. A systolic ejection murmur is heard along the right upper sternal border. The extremities are warm, and pulses are 2+ bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Propylthiouracil (PTU) is an antithyroid drug that is used in the medical treatment of hyperthyroidism, which this patient shows signs and symptoms of. However, PTU is usually indicated during the first trimester of pregnancy, whereas methimazole is usually the preferred antithyroid drug for most other cases because of its long duration of action and potency. Moreover, this patient should receive immediate control of her symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

Beta blockers (e.g., propranolol) are indicated for the immediate control of symptoms in patients with hyperthyroidism. This patient with anxiety, tremor, digital swelling, retraction of the eyelid, and irregular heartbeats most likely has hyperthyroidism. Thyroid hormones affect cardiac myocytes directly and also stimulate the proliferation of beta-adrenergic receptors, which can cause cardiac arrhythmias as seen in this patient. Beta blockers decrease the adrenergic tone and therefore reduce tachycardia, control hypertension, improve muscle weakness, tremor, and neuropsychiatric symptoms. Propranolol, in high doses, also decreases the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 by inhibiting the 5'-monodeiodinase enzyme. Thus, this patient should be started on a beta blocker, preferably propranolol, as soon as possible.

C) INCORRECT:

Main indications for digoxin treatment are atrial fibrillation (AF) and heart failure in treatment-resistant cases. Although this patient has an arrhythmia, which could be AF, it is accompanied by symptoms of thyrotoxicosis (tremor, anxiety, retraction of the eyelid). Hyperthyroid AF is usually resistant to the typical dose of digoxin, which requires a larger dose and thereby increases the risk of digoxin toxicity. Moreover, digoxin does not provide relief from the other manifestations of adrenergic hyperstimulation.

D) INCORRECT:

Amiodarone is used in the treatment of ventricular tachycardia and persisting ventricular fibrillation after unsuccessful defibrillation, as well as the long-term treatment of refractory supraventricular arrhythmia (e.g., atrial fibrillation). Because of the high levels of iodine in amiodarone, it may aggravate preexisting thyroid conditions. In this patient, who shows symptoms of supraventricular arrhythmia (palpitations and irregularly irregular pulse) and hyperthyroidism (anxiety, tremor, digital swelling, and retraction of the eyelid), amiodarone should only be considered if other treatment options fail.

E) INCORRECT:

Warfarin is an oral anticoagulant. Patients with atrial fibrillation (AF) are at increased risk of developing thromboembolic complications, which is why long-term anticoagulation is indicated when CHA2DS2-VASc score is ≥ 3 in women or when AF is caused by valvular disease. This patient's CHA2DS2-VASc score is 1 and although she presents with symptoms of AF (irregularly irregular pulse) and a systolic ejection murmur, her murmur is most likely due to the hyperdynamic circulation resulting from the increased adrenergic tone.

F) INCORRECT:

Diltiazem is classified as a class IV antiarrhythmic drug and is used to achieve rate control in patients with atrial fibrillation (AF), which is this patient's most likely arrhythmia. However, another therapeutic option is more commonly used and would also relieve thyrotoxic symptoms, such as tremor and anxiety.
questions.hint: The condition underlying this patient's arrhythmia can also cause heat intolerance, weight loss, and diarrhea.

questions.text: A previously healthy 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of palpitations that occur on minimal exertion and sometimes at rest. She has no chest discomfort or shortness of breath. She feels nervous and irritable most of the time and attributes these feelings to her boyfriend leaving her 2 months ago. Since then she has started exercising more frequently and taking a herbal weight-loss pill, and has lost 6.8 kg (15 lb) of weight. She finds it hard to fall asleep and awakens 1 hour before the alarm goes off each morning. She has been drinking 2 to 3 cups of coffee daily for the past 7 years and has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 3 years. Her temperature is 37.4°C (99.4°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 150/70 mm Hg. Examination shows moist palms. Neurologic examination shows a fine resting tremor of the hands. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ with a shortened relaxation phase. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Excessive consumption of stimulants such as caffeine, which is found in coffee and some weight-loss supplements, can cause restlessness, sleep disturbances, tachycardia, hyperreflexia, resting tremor, and palpitations. This patient's weight loss medication may be the source of her symptoms. However, her daily routine of drinking 2–3 cups of coffee is generally regarded as safe for regular consumption. Furthermore, her regular coffee consumption has been a longstanding habit and she is now likely to be well-tolerant to this level of caffeine intake. Therefore, coffee is unlikely to be the cause of her rather recent onset of symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytoma can also present with episodic or persistent hypertension, palpitations, and tachycardia as well as weight loss and diaphoresis (sweating) due to the massive release of catecholamines into the systemic circulation. If examined during such an episode, patients could also exhibit resting tremor and hyperreflexia. However, pheochromocytomas commonly cause throbbing headaches, nausea, pallor, and abdominal pain, none of which this patient has. Most importantly, patient's symptoms would generally have an episodic nature, which was not reported here.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute stress disorder is a trauma- and stressor-related disorder. To establish this diagnosis, a patient must meet a wide range of criteria that include arousal symptoms such as the sleep disturbance and irritability seen here, but also and more importantly a history of trauma as well as symptoms of intrusion, negative mood, dissociation, and avoidance. Furthermore, this patient's neurological findings of hyperreflexia and resting tremor suggest a different diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease in which autoantibodies against the thyroid gland lead to the gradual destruction of thyroid tissue. While hyperthyroidism can occasionally be present in acute phases of Hashimoto thyroiditis (Hashitoxicosis), the disease is typically asymptomatic in its early stages and only manifests with hypothyroidism in later stages. Hashimoto thyroiditis is, therefore, not the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Graves disease is an autoimmune disorder that causes hyperthyroidism and is characterized by the presence of stimulating TSH receptor autoantibodies. However, unlike this patient, individuals with Graves disease typically present with diffuse goiter, Graves ophthalmopathy, and pretibial myxedema.

F) CORRECT:

Over-the-counter weight-loss supplements and herbal products commonly contain thyroid hormones in amounts high enough to cause thyrotoxicosis. Other groups at high risk for factitious hyperthyroidism are medical personnel who have access to L-thyroxine and use it to lose weight, receive insurance compensation (malingering), or gain attention (Munchausen syndrome/factitious disorder). Goiter, which may be present in some forms of endogenous hyperthyroidism, is absent in patients with exogenous thyrotoxicosis. Low or undetectable thyroglobulin levels indicate that exogenous thyroid hormones have caused the thyroid gland to stop producing endogenous hormones and thus confirm the diagnosis. Treatment includes tapering and ceasing the exogenous hormone intake. Beta blockers can be considered for severely symptomatic patients.

G) INCORRECT:

While patients with generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) may present with irritability, restlessness, and sleep disturbance, patients typically do not show neurological findings such as the increased reflexes seen in this case. Furthermore, GAD is characterized by prolonged and excessive anxiety that is either unspecific or revolves around certain themes (e.g., health, work).
questions.hint: This patient presents with features of hyperthyroidism (palpitations, weight loss, sleep disturbance, irritability, fine tremors, and hyperreflexia). If a thyroid profile were to be done in this patient, the most likely results would be decreased thyroglobulin and TSH levels and increased T3 and T4 levels.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of irritability and frequent bowel movements. During this time, she has had a 6.8-kg (15-lb) weight loss. She has not had a change in appetite or diet. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.4°C (99.4°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 126/74 mm Hg. Examination shows moist palms. The thyroid gland is diffusely enlarged; there are no palpable nodules. Serum studies show a thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) concentration of 0.2 μU/mL, thyroxine (T4) concentration of 22 μg/dL, and antibodies against the TSH receptor. Which of the following treatment modalities is associated with the lowest rate of recurrence for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Subtotal thyroidectomy leaves a remnant of each lobe of the thyroid gland. Graves disease has a high recurrence rate when treated with this procedure. Surgical options that have a lower rate of recurrence include total thyroidectomy and near-total thyroidectomy. Indications for surgery to treat Graves disease include severe Graves ophthalmopathy, large goiters that cause tracheal and/or neural compression, gestational Graves disease (second trimester) in patients who cannot tolerate antithyroid drugs, and contraindications to antithyroid drugs (e.g., hypersensitivity reactions). Complications of surgery include hypoparathyroidism and damage to the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

B) CORRECT:

Among the treatment options for Graves disease, radioactive iodine ablation (RAIA) has the lowest recurrence rate. During this procedure, hyperfunctioning tissue takes up the radioactive iodine and is ablated. In patients with Graves disease, the entire thyroid gland hyperfunctions due to stimulatory antithyroid antibodies. Radioactive iodine thus ablates the whole gland and provides a permanent cure for hyperthyroidism. Pretreatment with antithyroid drugs is not necessary for patients with less severe hyperthyroidism.

RAIA can cause permanent hypothyroidism, especially in patients who receive high-dose therapy. More than half of patients eventually develop hypothyroidism and require long-term supplementation of thyroxine. Therefore, patients who undergo RAIA should receive regular monitoring of thyroid function tests. Contraindications to RAIA include pregnancy, breastfeeding, and severe Graves ophthalmopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Beta blockers like propranolol are used in the acute treatment of symptoms of sympathetic hyperactivity in patients with symptoms of hyperthyroidism (e.g., palpitations, tremor, lid retraction, neuropsychiatric symptoms). However, they play no role in the definitive treatment of hyperthyroidism.

D) INCORRECT:

Methimazole can be used as pretreatment before definitive treatment of patients with severe hyperthyroidism to rapidly achieve euthyroid status or as definitive treatment for some cases of mild hyperthyroidism. Definitive treatment with antithyroid drugs may take 1–2 years, and older studies conducted in the US show a recurrence rate of 70–80%. However, recurrence rates in Europe and Asia are much lower, and antithyroid drugs are often used as definitive treatment in these continents. In addition, long-term methimazole therapy is associated with rare but serious adverse effects such as hypersensitivity, agranulocytosis, and hepatotoxicity. In this young patient with less severe hyperthyroidism (thyroid hormone levels below 2–3 times normal concentrations), pretreatment is not necessary and, in the US, a different therapeutic approach that has a lower recurrence rate is preferred.

E) INCORRECT:

Iodides like oral potassium iodide (Lugol iodine solution) inhibit the release of thyroid hormones from the gland, which results in a rapid decrease in circulating thyroid hormone levels. Iodides are therefore useful as adjunctive treatment of hyperthyroidism or thyroid storm. However, iodides are not used as the sole or definitive treatment of hyperthyroidism because the thyroid gland overcomes the iodide block within a few weeks and uses the exogenous iodides to synthesize more thyroid hormones, which exacerbates hyperthyroidism.

F) INCORRECT:

Propylthiouracil can be used as a pretreatment before definitive treatment in patients with severe hyperthyroidism to rapidly achieve euthyroid status or as a definitive treatment. In this young patient with less severe hyperthyroidism (thyroid hormone levels below 2–3 times normal concentrations), pretreatment is not necessary and, in the US, a different therapeutic approach with a lower recurrence rate is preferred.
questions.hint: This woman's symptoms of hyperthyroidism, a diffuse goiter, and the presence of TSH receptor antibodies are highly suggestive of Graves disease.

questions.text: A 21-year-old primigravid woman comes to the physician at 10 weeks' gestation because of progressive fatigue for the past 3 weeks. She reports that she has had a 3.2-kg (7-lb) weight loss after conceiving despite an increase in appetite. She has become increasingly anxious and has trouble falling asleep. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. Medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 55 kg (120 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.4°C (99.4°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 150/70 mm Hg. The globes of the eyes are prominent. The thyroid gland is firm and diffusely enlarged. Neurologic examination shows a fine resting tremor of the hands. There is a midsystolic click at the apex and a grade 2/6 early systolic murmur at the upper left sternal border. Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone concentration is 0.1 μU/mL. An ECG is normal except for sinus tachycardia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lugol's iodine can cause a transient reduction in the levels of thyroid hormones (due to the Wolff-Chaikoff effect), but after 5–10 days serum iodine would increase the production of T3 and T4 and thus exacerbate the patient's hyperthyroidism. In patients with Graves disease, the Wolff-Chaikoff effect of iodine can be utilized 5–10 days before thyroidectomy to prevent a thyroid storm. However, thyroidectomy is contraindicated during the first trimester because of teratogenicity associated with anesthetic drugs and the increased risk of fetal loss after major surgery.

B) INCORRECT:

Thyroidectomy can be used to treat Graves disease. However, thyroidectomy is contraindicated during the first and third trimesters because of teratogenicity associated with anesthetic drugs, increased risk of fetal loss during the first trimester, and the increased risk of preterm labor during the third trimester. If thyroidectomy is indicated, it should be performed during the second half of the second trimester.

C) CORRECT:

For a pregnant woman with Graves disease, propylthiouracil (PTU) is the therapy of choice during the first trimester. PTU crosses the placenta less readily and is associated with a lower risk of birth defects when compared with methimazole. During therapy, T3 and T4 levels should be checked every 3 weeks and the dose of PTU should be decreased once the mother is euthyroid or only mildly hyperthyroid so that fetal hypothyroidism does not occur. Methimazole is the preferred antithyroid drug during the second and third trimesters as PTU is associated with a higher risk of hepatocellular damage and agranulocytosis when compared with methimazole.

D) INCORRECT:

Methimazole is the antithyroid drug of choice during the second and third trimesters. However, it is contraindicated during the first trimester because it is teratogenic and associated with congenital defects such as aplasia cutis, choanal atresia, esophageal atresia, and omphalocele (methimazole embryopathy).

E) INCORRECT:

The use of radioiodine (either diagnostic or therapeutic) is contraindicated during pregnancy because radioiodine can destroy the fetal thyroid gland and cause congenital hypothyroidism.

F) INCORRECT:

In pregnant women with Graves disease, observation without therapy would be appropriate during the first trimester if the patient was treated prior to becoming pregnant and has a stable euthyroid state with falling TSH receptor antibody (TRAb) levels. In pregnant women with untreated Graves disease, IgG TRAbs cross the placenta and stimulate the fetal thyroid, causing fetal thyromegaly and fetal thyrotoxicosis, which are associated with preterm delivery and high neonatal mortality of 10–20% (due to heart failure, tracheal compression caused by a goiter, infections, and/or thrombocytopenia). Untreated maternal hyperthyroidism is also associated with increased maternal mortality (due to pre-eclampsia, maternal heart failure, placental abruption, and/or thyroid storm).

G) INCORRECT:

Beta blockers such as propranolol and metoprolol are safe during pregnancy and can therefore be used as a part of initial therapy to reduce heart rate and treat symptoms of thyrotoxicosis (e.g., anxiety, palpitations, sweating) until the patient becomes euthyroid. However, atenolol is associated with an increased risk of fetal growth restriction; its use during pregnancy is therefore contraindicated.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features suggestive of Graves disease: hyperthyroidism (weight loss, fatigue, anxiety, insomnia, tachycardia, systolic murmur, ↓ TSH), Graves ophthalmopathy (exophthalmos), and a diffusely enlarged goiter.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician because of palpitations and irritability. Over the past 4 months, she has had several episodes of heart racing and skipping beats that lasted between 30 seconds and several hours. She has also been arguing with her husband more, often about the temperature being too warm. The patient has also lost 8.8-kg (19.4-lb) over the past 4 months, despite being less strict with her diet. She has mild asthma treated with inhaled bronchodilators. Her pulse is 102/min and blood pressure is 148/98 mm Hg. On physical examination, the skin is warm and moist. A mass is palpated in the anterior neck area. On laboratory studies, thyroid stimulating hormone is undetectable and there are antibodies against the thyrotropin-receptor. Thyroid scintigraphy shows diffusely increased iodine uptake. Two weeks later, a single oral dose of radioactive iodine is administered. This patient will most likely require which of the following in the long-term?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Near-total thyroidectomy may be required if RAIA fails to destroy thyroid tissue, leading to a recurrence of hyperthyroidism. Failure rates of RAIA range from 10–40%. Most patients undergo a second trial of RAIA before a decision to perform a thyroid surgery is made. Thyroid surgery is more difficult after RAIA as the gland is usually fibrotic. However, a more common outcome occurs in patients with Graves disease following RAIA.

B) INCORRECT:

Potassium iodide (KI) rapidly decreases thyroid hormone release from the gland and prevents synthesis of new hormones. KI is useful when rapid control of hyperthyroidism is required (e.g., thyroid storm, severe thyrotoxicosis). After RAIA, preformed thyroid hormone is released into circulation, transiently worsening the hyperthyroidism. KI can be used to control postablation hyperthyroidism (esp. in patients with allergies to antithyroid drugs) in patients > 60 years of age or those with cardiac comorbidities. This woman has no features of cardiac disease and is < 60 years old. In addition, postablation hyperthyroidism is transient, meaning long-term KI therapy is unnecessary.

C) INCORRECT:

After RAIA, preformed thyroid hormone is released into circulation, transiently worsening the hyperthyroidism. In patients with severe hyperthyroidism (poorly controlled with medications, highly elevated thyroid hormone levels), cardiac comorbidities, and age > 60 years, methimazole should be given before and after RAIA to achieve a euthyroid status. This patient does not fit any of these criteria. In addition, as postablation hyperthyroidism is transient, long-term use of methimazole is unnecessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Propranolol offers symptomatic relief from the adrenergic symptoms of hyperthyroidism (e.g., palpitations, heat intolerance, irritability). Propranolol may be given after RAIA to control the possible worsening of symptoms due to the release of preformed thyroid hormone into circulation, a common effect after RAIA. However, postablation hyperthyroidism is transient, meaning long-term propranolol therapy is unnecessary. In addition, propranolol is a nonselective beta blocker and is contraindicated in asthmatics because it can cause bronchoconstriction and precipitate an acute asthmatic attack.

E) CORRECT:

Radioactive iodine is only taken up by functioning thyroid tissue. Because the entire thyroid gland is hyperstimulated by thyrotropin-receptor antibodies in Graves disease, it will take up radioactive iodine and be destroyed. This effect often results in permanent hypothyroidism, which is easier to manage than Graves disease. Hypothyroidism usually develops within 3–6 months of RAIA and is treated with life-long L-thyroxine replacement therapy.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features of Graves disease: hyperthyroidism (palpitations, irritability, weight loss, heat intolerance, increased sweating, warm skin), a palpable goiter, thyrotropin-receptor antibodies, and diffuse iodine uptake of the thyroid gland. She received radioactive iodine ablation (RAIA), during which radioactive iodine is taken up by the thyroid gland, emits beta radiation, and destroys thyroid tissue.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of palpitations and anxiety for the past 2 months. She has had a 3.1-kg (7-lb) weight loss in this period. Her pulse is 112/min. Cardiac examination shows normal heart sounds with a regular rhythm. Neurologic examination shows a fine resting tremor of the hands; patellar reflexes are 3+ bilaterally with a shortened relaxation phase. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following sets of laboratory values is most likely on evaluation of blood obtained before treatment?



TSH
free T4
free T3
Thyroxine-binding globulin



A
↓
↓
↓
normal


B
↓
↑
↑
normal


C
↓
↑
normal
↑


D
↑
↓
↓
↓


E
↑
normal
normal
normal
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased TSH, free T3, and free T4 levels would be consistent with secondary hypothyroidism. In this condition, TSH secretion from the pituitary gland is impaired, which causes reduced thyroid hormone production and symptoms of hypothyroidism (e.g., weight gain, fatigue, hair loss, constipation). This patient's presentation is not consistent with hypothyroidism.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's symptoms are consistent with overt hyperthyroidism. Laboratory analysis would show elevated free T3 and T4 levels, with a compensatory decrease of TSH due to the negative feedback regulation of the hypothalamic–pituitary axis. Thyroxine-binding globulin is typically not affected in hyperthyroid patients. It can be elevated in pregnancy or decreased due to liver failure, for example, neither of which is the case here. The most common cause of hyperthyroidism is Graves disease, which is an autoimmune-mediated stimulation of the thyroid gland by TSH receptor antibodies.

C) INCORRECT:

These laboratory findings would be consistent with hyperthyroidism associated with pregnancy, in which high estrogen levels cause the thyroxine-binding globulin concentration to increase. Total T3 and T4 levels are elevated due to hyperthyroidism, while levels of free circulating thyroid hormone typically remain normal or only mildly elevated due to increased thyroid hormone binding. However, this patient's pregnancy test was negative, making a different set of laboratory findings more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Elevated TSH in the setting of decreased free T3 and T4 would be consistent with hypothyroidism, which is most commonly caused by Hashimoto thyroiditis. An additional decrease in thyroxine-binding globulin can be due to decreased production (e.g., liver failure), increased excretion (e.g., nephrotic syndrome), or certain medications (e.g., corticosteroids). This patient's symptoms are not consistent with hypothyroidism.

E) INCORRECT:

These laboratory findings would be consistent with subclinical hypothyroidism, which is characterized by elevated TSH and normal free thyroxine (T4) levels. Patients are typically asymptomatic or may have mild symptoms of hypothyroidism. This patient's symptoms are not consistent with subclinical hypothyroidism.
questions.hint: This patient presents with classic features of hyperthyroidism (palpitations, weight loss, irritability, fine tremors, and hyperreflexia).

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the physician for intermittent episodes of sharp chest pain and palpitations. She appears nervous. Her pulse is 115/min and irregularly irregular, and blood pressure is 139/86 mmHg. Examination shows a fine tremor on both hands and digital swelling; the extremities are warm. There is retraction of the right upper eyelid. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amiodarone is used in the treatment of ventricular tachycardia and persisting ventricular fibrillation (VF) after unsuccessful defibrillation, as well as the long-term treatment of refractory supraventricular arrhythmia (atrial fibrillation). Because of the high levels of iodine in amiodarone, it may aggravate pre-existing thyroid conditions. In this patient, who shows symptoms of supraventricular arrhythmia (palpitations and irregularly irregular pulse) and hyperthyroidism (anxiety, tremor, digital swelling, and retraction of the eyelid), amiodarone should only be considered if other treatment options fail.

B) INCORRECT:

Propylthiouracil (PTU) is an antithyroid drug that is used in the medical treatment for hyperthyroidism, of which this patient shows sign and symptoms. However, symptomatic treatment should be started for immediate control of symptoms. Furthermore, while PTU is usually indicated in pregnant patients during the first trimester, methimazole is the preferred antithyroid drug for all other cases because of its long duration of action and potency.

C) INCORRECT:

Warfarin is an oral anticoagulant. Patients with atrial fibrillation (AF) are at increased risk of developing thromboembolic complications, which is why long-term anticoagulation is indicated in women when the CHA2DS2-VASc score is ≥ 3 or when AF is caused by valvular disease. Although this patient has features of AF (irregularly irregular pulse), her CHA2DS2-VASc score is 1 and she has no history of valvular disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Methimazole is an antithyroid drug used in the medical treatment for hyperthyroidism (except during the first trimester of pregnancy), of which this patient shows signs and symptoms. However, symptomatic treatment should be started for immediate control of symptoms.

E) CORRECT:

Propranolol is indicated for the immediate control of symptoms in patients with hyperthyroidism. This patient with anxiety, tremor, warm skin, digital swelling, retraction of the eyelid, and irregular heartbeats most likely has hyperthyroidism. Thyroid hormones affect cardiac myocytes directly and also stimulate proliferation of beta-adrenergic receptors, which can cause cardiac arrhythmias as seen in this patient. Beta blockers decrease the adrenergic tone and therefore improve tachycardia, hypertension, muscle weakness, tremor, and neuropsychiatric symptoms. Propranolol, in high doses, also decreases the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 by inhibiting the 5'-monodeiodinase enzyme.
questions.hint: The condition underlying this patient's arrhythmia causes a state of adrenergic hyperactivity.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of tremor, diarrhea, and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss. Her pulse is 110/min. Examination shows protrusion of the eyeball when looking forward. A bruit is heard over the anterior neck on auscultation. Serum studies show autoantibodies to the thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor. The patient decides to undergo definitive treatment for her condition with a radioactive tracer. The success of this treatment directly depends on the activity of which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The success of radioactive iodine ablation directly depends on a sodium/iodide symporter (NIS), a transmembrane carrier located on the basolateral side of thyroid follicular cells that transports iodine into thyroid tissue. In the case of radioactive ablation, radioactive iodine is taken up by the NIS the same way as natural iodine, thereby destroying (i.e., ablating) any thyroid tissue. While undergoing RAI, competitive inhibitors of NIS like perchlorate, pertechnate, and high-dose potassium iodine should be avoided. However, in cases of accidental exposure to radiation, high-dose potassium iodine can prevent uptake of radioactive isotopes into the thyroid gland.

B) INCORRECT:

Lysosomal proteases are not the target of radioactive tracers (nor any other antithyroid therapy) as they do not take part in the uptake of iodine. Instead, they degrade the prohormone thyroglobulin into T4 and T3 after its endocytosis into thyroid cells.

C) INCORRECT:

Type 1 deiodinase is a hormone-activating enzyme that converts thyroxine (T4) to triiodothyronine (T3). Although it is one of two enzymes targeted by propylthiouracil (PTU), a thioamide sometimes used in the treatment of hyperthyroidism, it does not participate in iodine uptake and is thus not a target of radioactive tracers. In addition, thioamides are usually not used as a definitive treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Thyroxine-binding globulin does not transport iodine, including radioactive iodine, into cells. Reduced TBG levels can be found in hyperthyroidism as well as in nephrotic syndrome and liver failure. However, TBG is not a target in the treatment of Graves disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Treatment of Graves disease is often initiated by thioamides (e.g., methimazole, carbimazole, propylthiouracil), which prevent the synthesis of thyroid hormones by inhibiting thyroid peroxidase, an anion-oxidizing enzyme. However, thioamides are usually not used as a definitive treatment. When reaching a euthyroid state, treatment with radioactive tracers or thyroidectomy is the next step.
questions.hint: Diarrhea, weight loss, tremor, and tachycardia are symptoms of hyperthyroidism. The findings of exophthalmos and a cervical bruit suggest Graves disease, which is confirmed by the presence of (activating) TSH-receptor autoantibodies. Radioactive iodine ablation is one form of definitive treatment for this condition.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 36 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of irritability, palpitations, heat intolerance, and frequent bowel movements for the last 5 months. She has received no prenatal care. Her pulse is 118/min and blood pressure is 133/80 mm Hg. She appears anxious. There is a fine tremor in the hands and ophthalmologic examination shows bilateral exophthalmos. The skin is warm and moist to touch. This patient’s child is most likely to have which of the following complications at birth?

choices.text: Umbilical hernia and erosive scalp lesion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bradycardia (due to heart block) and annular rash are features seen in neonatal SLE. SLE is a multisystem autoimmune disease that preferentially affects women of childbearing age and can lead to neonatal SLE via the passage of maternal antibodies across the placenta. However, typical findings in the mother would include fever, fatigue, a malar rash (butterfly rash), myalgias, and arthritis, none of which are present in this woman.

B) INCORRECT:

An umbilical hernia and erosive scalp lesions in a neonate would be most consistent with methimazole use during the first trimester of pregnancy. The teratogenic effects of methimazole include aplasia cutis congenita, craniofacial malformations (facial dysmorphism, choanal atresia), gastrointestinal malformations (esophageal atresia with or without tracheoesophageal fistula), abdominal wall defects (umbilical hernia), ventricular septal defects, and defects of the ocular and urinary systems. Since this mother has no history of methimazole use, umbilical hernia and erosive scalp lesions would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Macrosomia and consequential shoulder dystocia in a neonate are most commonly seen in uncontrolled gestational diabetes mellitus. In diabetic mothers, chronic hyperglycemia causes fetal hyperinsulinemia and islet cell hyperplasia. This, in turn, leads to an increase in fetal insulin-like growth factor and growth hormone, resulting in macrosomia and subsequent risk of birth injuries such as shoulder dystocia. However, gestational diabetes typically presents with polyuria, polydipsia, and fatigue, none of which this mother has.

D) INCORRECT:

A mechanical holosystolic murmur and tetany in a neonate would be consistent with DiGeorge syndrome, which is caused by a deletion in 22q11.2. The clinical presentation is variable and includes features such as congenital heart defects, craniofacial abnormalities, cleft palate, and thymus/parathyroid aplasia or hypoplasia. Murmurs are attributable to structural heart disease and tetany arises from the hypocalcemia of hypoparathyroidism. This mother presents with signs and symptoms most concerning for maternal Graves disease, which is not associated with neonatal DiGeorge syndrome.

E) CORRECT:

Poor weight gain and stridor are serious neonatal manifestations that may be seen in untreated maternal Graves disease. During pregnancy, TSH receptor antibodies cross the placenta, leading to neonatal Graves disease and thyrotoxicosis. Neonatal thyrotoxicosis is most often self-limiting, but severe disease can result in tachycardia, diaphoresis, failure to thrive, hyperphagia, stridor (due to compressive goiter), and microcephaly (attributable to craniosynostosis).
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms of irritability, palpitations, heat intolerance, in conjunction with physical exam findings of tachycardia, exophthalmos, and warm moist skin are highly suggestive of Graves disease.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter because of a 1-month history of fatigue and a 3.5-kg (7-lb) weight loss. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and Alzheimer's dementia. She lives with her daughter and requires assistance with all of her banking and meal preparation. Her daughter has hypothyroidism, but there is no other history of serious illness in the family. The patient does not remember the names of her medications but says she takes them every day. Her pulse is 114/min and blood pressure is 148/101 mm Hg. Physical examination shows warm skin and a tremor. The thyroid gland is not palpable. The serum thyroid stimulating hormone level is undetectable. Histological examination of a thyroid biopsy shows follicular atrophy. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Graves disease is an autoimmune condition in which TSH-receptor autoantibodies lead to overstimulation of the thyroid gland, causing hyperthyroidism and low TSH levels. This patient, however, does not have classic Graves disease features such as exophthalmos, goiter, and/or pretibial myxedema. Furthermore, a thyroid biopsy would show diffuse hyperplasia, not the follicular atrophy seen in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

The combination of hyperthyroidism, an undetectable TSH level, and a thyroid biopsy showing follicular atrophy is most likely secondary to an unintentional exogenous intake of thyroid hormones. This patient's daughter has a history of hypothyroidism, for which she likely is taking levothyroxine. The patient's cognitive impairment has most likely led her to mistakenly take her daughter's medication, which has caused her to develop hyperthyroidism.

C) INCORRECT:

Granulomatous thyroiditis is a transient inflammatory condition associated with granuloma formation that can initially cause hyperthyroidism. However, it classically manifests with tender goiter, elevated ESR, and jaw pain. Furthermore, a biopsy would show diffuse granulomatous inflammation, not the follicular atrophy seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased iodine exposure can cause hyperthyroidism and occasionally occurs following treatment with high-dose iodine for autonomous thyroid nodules. However, this is a very rare cause of hyperthyroidism and would normally coincide with the presence of nodules or a goiter. Furthermore, a biopsy would demonstrate tissue hyperplasia, not the follicular atrophy seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Medullary thyroid cancer is a malignant neoplasm of the parafollicular C cells that can cause hyperthyroidism. However, it is an extremely rare cause of hyperthyroidism and would manifest with thyroid nodules or a neck mass. Furthermore, a biopsy would demonstrate parafollicular cell hyperplasia, not the follicular atrophy seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient with mild cognitive impairment presents with unintentional weight loss, warm and moist skin, tachycardia, hypertension, and tremor, which are clinical symptoms of hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by a nurse 30 minutes after receiving scheduled radiation therapy for papillary thyroid cancer. After the radioisotope was ingested, the physician realized that a much larger fixed dose was given instead of the appropriate dose based on radiation dosimetry. Administration of which of the following is most likely to prevent complications from this exposure?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amifostine acts as an oxygen-free radical scavenger and is used to prevent nephrotoxic side effects in patients receiving chemotherapy with platinum-based, alkylating agents (e.g., cisplatin, carboplatin, and oxaliplatin). Amifostine can prevent salivary gland damage in the case of head and neck radiation or radioiodine therapy. However, it cannot protect the thyroid gland against radioactive iodine toxicity because it does not prevent the uptake of radioactive iodine in the thyroid gland.

B) INCORRECT:

Propylthiouracil, an antithyroid drug that inhibits thyroid peroxidase and the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3, is indicated in the treatment of hyperthyroidism and is the drug of choice in thyroid storm. It would not be used to treat potential radioactive iodine toxicity because it does not prevent the uptake of radioactive iodine in the thyroid gland.

C) INCORRECT:

Mercaptoethanesulfonate (MESNA) potentially inactivates the toxic metabolite acrolein and is therefore used to prevent hemorrhagic cystitis in patients undergoing chemotherapy with cyclophosphamide or ifosfamide. It would not be used to treat potential radioactive iodine toxicity because it does not prevent the uptake of radioactive iodine in the thyroid gland.

D) CORRECT:

Potassium iodide should be administered immediately to prevent complications of high-dose radioiodine therapy (I131). In the case of excess exposure to radioactive iodine (e.g., in patients undergoing radioactive iodine ablation or after a nuclear accident), potassium iodide is used to decrease radioactive iodine uptake by the thyroid gland, which decreases the risk of radiation thyroiditis and radiation-induced thyroid cancer. When administered immediately after radioactive iodine overdose, nonradioactive iodine in potassium iodide competes with radioactive I131 and prevents uptake into the thyroid gland. Potassium iodide also inhibits the release of thyroid hormone by preventing the proteolytic cleavage of T3 and T4 from thyroglobulin. Therefore, it can be used as an adjunct therapy in hyperthyroidism and thyroid storm, as well as a pretreatment before thyroid surgery.
Image Description:

Left side: effect of drugs on the thyroid gland.
- Thionamides inhibit thyroid peroxidase (TPO), which blocks thyroid hormone synthesis.
- Lithium inhibits the release of thyroid hormones and may be used off-label in a thyroid storm.
- Perchlorate inhibits the sodium-iodine cotransporter in the membrane, which blocks iodide uptake in the thyroid gland.

Right side: drug effects in the periphery. A number of drugs inhibit the enzyme deiodinase, which blocks the peripheral conversion of T4 to the active form T3.

E) INCORRECT:

Methimazole, an antithyroid drug that inhibits thyroid peroxidase and decreases thyroid hormone synthesis, is indicated in the treatment of hyperthyroidism and thyroid storm. Methimazole can be used prior to the administration of radioactive iodine therapy in patients with Graves disease to control the initial hyperthyroid phase. It would not be used to treat potential radioactive iodine toxicity because it does not prevent the uptake of radioactive iodine in the thyroid gland.

F) INCORRECT:

Dexrazoxane, an iron-chelating agent, is used to prevent cardiotoxicity associated with anthracycline-based chemotherapeutic agents such as doxorubicin and daunorubicin. It would not be used to treat potential radioactive iodine toxicity because it does not prevent the uptake of radioactive iodine in the thyroid gland.
questions.hint: High-dose radioiodine (I131) is used as adjunct therapy in the case of differentiated thyroid cancer (e.g., papillary thyroid cancer, follicular thyroid cancer). The drug that is used to treat an acute overdose of radioiodine is also used to treat thyroid storm because it temporarily decreases the activity of thyroid peroxidase (Wolff-Chaikoff effect).

questions.text: A previously healthy 29-year-old man comes to the physician for a 2-month history of intermittent double vision and a tremor of the fingers. He is a physician doing his residency in general surgery; the tremor and periods of double vision have kept him from participating in surgeries during the past month. During this time, he has also had difficulty sleeping, increased frequency of bowel movements, and a 7-kg (15-lb) weight loss despite an increased appetite. He has no history of previous illness and takes no medications. He has been drinking 3 to 4 cups of coffee daily for the past 9 years. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.4°F), pulse is 105/min and regular, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 145/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows moist palms and a fine, low-amplitude tremor of the fingers when he extends his arms in front of his body. There is retraction of the upper eye lids, anterior protrusion of both eyeballs, and restricted convergence during accommodation reflex testing. Neurologic examination shows normal muscle strength, bulk, and tone. Deep tendon reflexes are hyperactive. There is no dysmetria and sensation is intact. Serum studies show a thyroid-stimulating hormone concentration of 0.03 μU/mL, thyroxine concentration of 19 μg/dL, and antibodies against the TSH receptor. Thyroid scintigraphy shows diffusely increased iodine uptake. Treatment with propranolol is initiated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thyroid lobectomy is the preferred treatment option for patients with hyperthyroidism due to localized autonomous thyroid nodules (e.g., toxic adenoma). Graves disease affects the entire thyroid, as seen on this patient's thyroid scintigraphy, and lobectomy is not a treatment option in Graves disease. Furthermore, this patient has acute thyrotoxicosis; thyroid surgery is not recommended at this point in treatment because manipulation of the thyroid could lead to thyroid storm.

B) INCORRECT:

Near-total thyroidectomy is a treatment option to establish long-term euthyroidism in patients with Graves disease and in those with concomitant Graves orbitopathy. This patient has acute thyrotoxicosis; thyroid surgery is not recommended at this point in treatment because manipulation of the thyroid could lead to thyroid storm.

C) CORRECT:

Initial management of thyrotoxicosis due to Graves disease consists of beta blockers (e.g., propranolol) for immediate control of symptoms (e.g., tachycardia) and antithyroid drugs (ATDs) such as methimazole for 4–8 weeks to establish euthyroidism prior to any further steps in treatment (e.g., surgery). Long-term euthyroid control in patients with Graves disease complicated by moderate-to-severe Graves orbitopathy can be achieved either with long-term ATDs or with surgery (near-total thyroidectomy). Radioactive iodine ablation is only a treatment option in patients with mild Graves orbitopathy and is not recommended in moderate-to-severe disease because it can worsen orbitopathy. Management of ocular symptoms consists of symptomatic therapy, eye-protection methods (e.g., sunglasses, artificial tears), and immunosuppressive drugs (e.g., steroids) because Graves orbitopathy is the result of an autoimmune reaction of the orbital tissue. Establishing euthyroidism is recommended in all patients with Graves orbitopathy to prevent deterioration of orbitopathy. Furthermore, noncontrast CT scan (to avoid iodine uptake) or MRI should be performed in patients with moderate-to-severe Graves orbitopathy to evaluate disease severity.

D) INCORRECT:

Radioactive iodine ablation (RAIA) is a treatment option to establish long-term euthyroidism in patients with Graves disease. However, RAIA is not recommended for patients with concomitant moderate-to-severe Graves orbitopathy because it can worsen orbitopathy. Furthermore, this patient has acute thyrotoxicosis, which should be treated prior to any further steps in treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Tocilizumab therapy is a second-line treatment option for patients with moderate-to-severe Graves orbitopathy. This drug may be used for patients whose ocular symptoms are refractory to high-dose glucocorticoids.
questions.hint: Thyrotoxicosis with elevated serum antibodies against the TSH receptor (TRAbs) is diagnostic of Graves disease, which in this patient is complicated by moderate Graves orbitopathy, as indicated by intermittent diplopia and exophthalmos. This complication should be taken into account when addressing this patient's hyperthyroidism.

questions.text:
One hour after emergency cesarean delivery because of severe fetal distress, a 26-year-old woman becomes agitated and develops nausea and vomiting. Examination prior to delivery showed clear amniotic fluid. The procedure was performed under general anesthesia. Blood loss was normal. The immediate postoperative period was uncomplicated. The patient says that pregnancy was uncomplicated except for occasional episodes of diarrhea that started in the second trimester. She received no prenatal care. She has major depressive disorder. Her only medication is fluoxetine, which she stopped taking when she learned of her pregnancy. She appears anxious. Her temperature is 41.1°C (106.0°F), pulse is 141/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 155/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows profuse sweating and a fine tremor of both hands. Abdominal examination shows a dry, slightly erythematous surgical site and a firm uterus. There is no vaginal bleeding. Examination of the eyes shows bilateral elevation of the eyelids on a downward gaze. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.6 g/dL


Leukocyte count
8400/mm3



Platelet count
282,000/mm3



Serum



 Na+

142 mEq/L


 Cl-

103 mEq/L


 K+

4.6 mEq/L


 Creatinine
0.9 mg/dL


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient's tachycardia, tachypnea, profuse sweating, anxiety, and tremor after emergency cesarean delivery are consistent with an adrenergic reaction to postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). However, she has a firm uterus and no signs of vaginal bleeding, which makes PPH (e.g., due to uterine atony) less likely. Furthermore, hypertension, fever, and eye examination findings are consistent with another diagnosis.

B) CORRECT:

This patient presents with clinical features of thyrotoxicosis (e.g., hypertension, fine tremor) most likely due to hyperthyroidism as a result of undiagnosed Graves disease, as indicated by a history of diarrhea and the findings of lid lag. The combination of thyrotoxicosis and symptoms of hypermetabolism (profuse sweating, hyperpyrexia, tachycardia, acute agitation, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and anxiety) indicates thyroid storm, which is a rare and life-threatening complication of hyperthyroidism. Triggers include stress-related catecholamine surge (e.g., nonthyroidal surgery, anesthesia induction, labor) and iatrogenic causes (e.g., thyroid surgery, iodine contrast application).

Thyroid storm has a high mortality rate and patients should receive aggressive treatment with fluids, beta-blockers, antithyroid drugs, external cooling, and antipyretics such as acetaminophen. If left untreated, it can lead to acute decompensated heart failure, arrhythmias, acute lung edema, and respiratory failure.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient underwent general anesthesia, which can trigger malignant hyperthermia (MH). This condition can manifest with symptoms of hypermetabolism (e.g., tachycardia, hyperpyrexia), similar to those seen in this patient. However, MH typically starts intraoperatively, whereas this patient's symptoms began one hour after emergency cesarean delivery when she was already extubated. Furthermore, typical findings of MH, such as muscle rigidity, are not seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient developed hypertension after delivery, which could suggest preeclampsia. However, diagnosis of eclampsia (a severe complication of preeclampsia) requires the presence of generalized convulsive seizures or coma, neither of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, the patient does not have any additional features of preeclampsia, such as signs of proteinuria (e.g., edema) or organ damage (e.g., increased creatinine).

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has some features of serotonin syndrome (SS), such as autonomic dysfunction (tachycardia, sweating), fever, and agitation. However, she is no longer taking fluoxetine, and without a triggering substance, SS is highly unlikely. Furthermore, this syndrome typically manifests with neuromuscular excitability (hyperreflexia), which is not found in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

This patient has some clinical features of systemic inflammatory response syndrome such as hyperthermia, tachycardia, and tachypnea. However, there is no evidence of an underlying infection (e.g., leukocytosis, malodorous, purulent amniotic fluid), making sepsis unlikely. In addition, this patient's history of diarrhea, tremor, and eye examination findings are consistent with another diagnosis.

G) INCORRECT:

This patient underwent emergency cesarean delivery, which could precipitate an adrenal crisis in an individual with underlying adrenal insufficiency (e.g., due to pituitary dysfunction). Although symptoms of an adrenal crisis include nausea and vomiting, this condition also manifests with severe hypotension. In contrast, this patient has hypertension and diaphoresis, which are signs of a hyperadrenergic state.
questions.hint: This patient most likely had an undiagnosed condition, which was exacerbated by cesarean delivery.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of nail changes. She says that her nails look “so ugly” that she is afraid to show her hands in public. The changes began on the fourth finger of each hand before progressing to all of her fingers and toes. Treatment with terbinafine has provided no relief. During the same time, she has also noticed that she is perspiring more than usual. The patient has not had any fever, cough, or changes in bowel habits. Her menses occur at irregular 40- and 50-day intervals. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She has a seizure disorder and a history of migraine headaches. Current medications are valproic acid and over-the-counter ibuprofen. She has followed a strict vegan diet since the age of 22 years. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 50 kg (110 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 147/63 mm Hg. Physical examination shows nonpitting plaques on the shins. Examination of the hands shows thickened nails with distal white discoloration. There is a distal separation of the nail plates of her fourth digits from the nail beds. There is no pain or swelling of the finger joints. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's nail changes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic undernutrition from dietary restriction can result in menstrual irregularities and micronutrient deficiencies. Iron deficiency can result in nail changes, and severe anemia may lead to tachycardia and widened pulse pressure. However, nail changes due to iron deficiency include brittle nails and koilonychia rather than onycholysis. In addition, excessive sweating and nonpitting plaques on the shins are not typical features of either iron deficiency or undernutrition.

B) INCORRECT:

Psoriasis can cause nail changes (e.g., onycholysis, nail pitting, oil drop sign) and plaques on the extensor surfaces of the extremities. However, the menstrual irregularities and vasomotor features (e.g., excessive sweating, systolic hypertension) seen in this patient are not manifestations of psoriasis.
Image Description:

The middle finger shows numerous superficial, round depressions (nail pits; examples indicated by arrowheads) caused by deficient keratinization. Both the ring and the middle finger show distal separation of the nail plate (onycholysis; green overlay). The index finger appears mostly normal.

Nail pitting and onycholysis are typical features of psoriasis with nail involvement.

C) INCORRECT:

Valproic acid may cause onycholysis, but nonpitting plaques on the shins, menstrual changes, and vasomotor features (e.g., excessive sweating, systolic hypertension) are not common. Other adverse effects of valproic acid include hair loss, a pruritic rash (due to drug-induced hypersensitivity syndrome), weight gain, hepatotoxicity, pancreatitis, gastrointestinal distress, and tremor.

D) CORRECT:

Nail changes (e.g., onycholysis) and hair loss are dermatological manifestations of hyperthyroidism as well as hypothyroidism. Excessive sweating, oligomenorrhea, tachycardia, and systolic hypertension (with widened pulse pressure) indicate that hyperthyroidism is the most likely cause of this patient's nail changes. The presence of pretibial myxedema (nonpitting plaques and/or nodules on the shins) indicates that this patient's hyperthyroidism is due to Graves disease. Patients with Graves disease can also develop nail clubbing due to thyroid acropachy in the late stages of the disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Menopause occurs in women 45–55 years of age and can cause episodic vasomotor symptoms (e.g., excessive sweating, tachycardia). Also, during the menopausal transition, menses become irregular and decrease in frequency. However, this patient has onycholysis and nonpitting plaques, which are not features of menopause.
questions.hint: Thickened nails with distal white discoloration and separation of the nail plate are consistent with onycholysis.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 40-year-old man reports a 12-month history of weight loss (6.8 kg), worsening exertional dyspnea, palpitations, and sweating.
On examination, he has a resting heart rate of 110 beats per minute and otherwise normal vital signs. He is thin and perspiring mildly. He has an eyelid lag with a downward gaze and no proptosis. His thyroid gland is slightly enlarged and nontender; there is an overlying bruit but no discrete nodules. His reflexes are brisk, and his proximal muscle strength is rated 4/5 in his arms and legs.
Laboratory evaluation reveals a thyroid-stimulating hormone level of <0.005 μU/mL (reference range, 0.5–4.7) and a free thyroxine level of 4.5 ng/dL (0.8–1.8).
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A toxic multinodular goiter would most likely be apparent on examination in the form of a nodule(s) and asymmetry.

B) CORRECT:

The presence of a thyroid bruit (which reflects increased blood flow to the thyroid) in a patient with thyrotoxicosis is highly suggestive of Graves disease.

Key learning point: The presence of a thyroid bruit and chronic symptoms in a patient with thyrotoxicosis is highly suggestive of Graves disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Most forms of thyroiditis resolve within 2 to 3 months; thus, the presence of symptoms for 12 months makes the diagnoses of silent or subacute thyroiditis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Riedel thyroiditis is a rare fibrosing condition of the thyroid that is not usually associated with hyperthyroidism.

E) INCORRECT:

Subacute thyroiditis, in particular, is generally painful and is manifested by a tender gland on examination. Most forms of thyroiditis resolve within 2 to 3 months; thus, the presence of symptoms for 12 months makes the diagnoses of silent or subacute thyroiditis unlikely.

questions.text:
An 86-year-old woman with a history of coronary artery disease and hypertension is transferred to a rehabilitation facility 5 days after undergoing coronary stenting for symptomatic angina. Her medications are aspirin 81 mg daily, clopidogrel 75 mg daily, and hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily, with which her hypertension is well controlled.
She reports feeling anxious. Her heart rate is 120 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 132/85 mm Hg. She is mildly diaphoretic and tremulous. Electrocardiography confirms the presence of sinus tachycardia.
Laboratory testing reveals the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Thyroid-stimulating hormone (μU/mL)
0.05
0.5–4.7


Free thyroxine (ng/dL)
2.9
0.8–1.8


Thyroid peroxidase antibody (IU/mL)
12
<20


Which one of the following conditions is the most likely explanation of the patient’s current presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Riedel thyroiditis is a manifestation of a systemic fibrosis, wherein a progressive fibrosis of the thyroid gland gradually results, most commonly, in hypothyroidism when thyroid function abnormalities occur. It is very rare and has been shown to respond to treatment with glucocorticoids and tamoxifen.

B) CORRECT:

Patients exposed to a clinically significant amount of iodine-containing contrast medium, such as during this patient’s recent percutaneous coronary intervention, are at risk for contrast-induced thyrotoxicosis if they have underlying thyroid disease, most commonly multinodular goiter with some degree of autonomous thyroid hormone production.

Key learning point: Patients with multinodular goiter or Graves disease, especially older adults or those with dietary iodine deficiency, are at increased risk for thyrotoxicosis after exposure to iodine-containing contrast medium.

C) INCORRECT:

Hashimoto thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism. Although it can initially manifest with a hyperthyroid phase, this is uncommon and is unlikely to be triggered by iodine exposure. Silent thyroiditis, associated with the release of preformed thyroid hormones and potentially recognized as the thyrotoxic phase of Hashimoto, would likely be associated with an elevated thyroid peroxidase antibody titer.

D) INCORRECT:

Subacute thyroiditis is associated with recent viral infection, is typically very painful, and would not be expected to be triggered by exposure to contrast medium.

E) INCORRECT:

Struma ovarii results from a rare form of ovarian teratoma that contains thyroid tissue. Thyroid symptoms are rarely the presenting feature. Exposure to radiographic contrast would be unlikely to precipitate symptomatic hyperthyroidism.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man presents with palpitations and insomnia. He reports being well until 7 months ago, when he started a new exercise regimen. Since then, he has noticed intermittent palpitations described as fast, forceful, regular heartbeats, both at rest and with exertion. He has also noticed a poor sleep pattern but no other issues. He has lost 10 kg of body weight.
Physical examination shows apparent slight anxiety but no clinical distress. His vital signs are as follows: a heart rate of 122 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 142/61 mm Hg, an oxygen saturation of 98% while he is breathing ambient air, and a BMI of 32.4. The patient’s palms are diaphoretic, and there is a slight tremor.
Electrocardiography reveals sinus tachycardia. Laboratory testing shows a thyroid-stimulating hormone level of 0.006 μU/mL (reference range, 0.5–4.7) and a free thyroxine level of 5.2 ng/dL (0.8–1.8).
Scanning with iodine-123 shows no radiotracer uptake in the region of the thyroid bed. Less than 1% of the radioiodine dose is measured to have been absorbed into the gland 5 hours after administration.
Which one of the following questions is most likely to identify the cause of this patient’s clinically persistent thyrotoxicosis?

choices.text: Have you been taking any supplements to help with weight loss?
Have you been exposed to ionizing radiation?
Do you have a family history of thyroid disease?
Do you have dry, itchy, or swollen eyes?
Do you currently have any discomfort or pain in the neck?

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Ingestion of exogenous thyroid hormone (thyrotoxicosis factitia) results in typical laboratory and clinical features of hyperthyroidism but is associated with a low uptake of radioiodine. Thyroid hormone is occasionally included as an ingredient in weight-loss remedies and hence asking about this would be the most likely way to yield a diagnosis for this patient.

Key learning point: A patient who has several months of persistent thyrotoxicosis and a low uptake of radioiodine can be diagnosed with exogenous hyperthyroidism.

B) INCORRECT:

A history of irradiation to the thyroid is important in the evaluation of a thyroid nodule but of little significance in the evaluation of the thyrotoxic patient.

C) INCORRECT:

A family history of thyroid disease does not reliably discriminate among the various causes of hyperthyroidism.

D) INCORRECT:

Dry, swollen, or itchy eyes can occur with ophthalmic involvement in Graves disease. However, Graves disease is associated with an increased, not decreased, uptake of radioiodine.

E) INCORRECT:

Asking about neck pain is prudent when the suspected diagnosis is subacute thyroiditis. However, when the patient’s symptoms extend beyond 2 months, the diagnosis of subacute thyroiditis is unlikely.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man reports fatigue and an unintentional weight loss of 3.6 kg during the past 8 weeks. He has a history of atrial fibrillation and coronary artery disease. His current medications are aspirin, lisinopril, amiodarone, rivaroxaban, and sublingual nitroglycerin as needed.
His heart rate is irregular, approximately 122 beats per minute. He appears restless and is mildly diaphoretic. His thyroid gland is palpable but not enlarged, with no nodules and no tenderness. There is no chemosis or exophthalmos. His lungs are normal on auscultation.
Neurologic examination is notable only for symmetrically brisk reflexes. Electrocardiography shows atrial fibrillation. A laboratory workup is notable only for a thyroid-stimulating hormone level of 0.015 μU/mL (reference range, 0.5–4.7).
In addition to starting a beta-blocker, which one of the following approaches would be the best initial treatment for this patient’s thyrotoxicosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thyroidectomy is sometimes necessary but is not usually the initial treatment for amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Although discontinuing the amiodarone may ultimately be necessary if feasible from a cardiac perspective, the effect of discontinuation has been reported to be variable and may not be clinically apparent for many months, given the drug’s extremely long half-life.

C) INCORRECT:

Radioiodine is unlikely to be helpful in amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis because the patient’s thyroid is already saturated with iodine from the amiodarone therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

A saturated solution of potassium iodide is used to treat thyroid storm, which this patient does not have.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s clinical features are most typical of amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis, which has two types:

• Type 1 is caused by an iodine load leading to excess production of thyroid hormone. It is more common in patients with autonomous thyroid tissue (either multinodular goiter or Graves disease) and in countries with low iodine content in the diet.
• Type 2 is caused by destruction of the thyroid gland from the direct effect of amiodarone. It is more common in the United States than type 1.

Clinically, differentiating type 1 amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis from the more common type 2 is difficult, and empiric treatment is usually started. In the United States, empiric treatment consists of prednisone 40 to 60 mg daily, which will treat type 2 amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis. For type 1 amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis, methimazole 40 mg daily can be added if prednisone is ineffective. Both drugs can be started at once if the patient is very ill. Usually, type 2 amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis responds to prednisone quickly (within one week), whereas type 1 amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis is slower to respond.

Graves disease should be considered in the differential diagnosis. It can be distinguished from amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis by the presence of goiter, thyroid bruit, and exophthalmos. In the absence of these typical signs, measurement of thyroid-stimulating hormone-receptor antibody titers may confirm Graves disease.

Key learning point: Amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis is best treated with a glucocorticoid, with the addition of an antithyroid drug if needed.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with anterior neck pain, palpitations, and night sweats. She was well until 2 weeks ago, when a low-grade fever and myalgias developed, followed by the neck pain, for which she has been taking acetaminophen and ibuprofen.
On physical examination, the patient has a heart rate of 124 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 142/55 mm Hg, and a temperature of 38.3°C. The thyroid gland is slightly enlarged. The left lobe of the thyroid is very tender on palpation, with no palpable nodules. The lymph nodes are slightly enlarged bilaterally.
Laboratory evaluation reveals a normal basic metabolic panel and a normal complete blood count. Other laboratory findings include an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 89 mm/hr (reference range, 1–25), a thyroid-stimulating hormone level of 0.009 μU/mL (0.5–4.7), and a free thyroxine level of 4.9 ng/dL (0.8–1.8).
What is the most likely natural history of this patient’s disorder?

choices.text: Progression to a rock-hard fibrotic goiter
Recurrent episodes of thyrotoxicosis separated by periods of euthyroidism
Spontaneous resolution of thyrotoxicosis followed by transient hypothyroidism

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Riedel thyroiditis manifests with goiter but not typically tenderness or thyrotoxicosis. The goiter is usually slowly progressing and rock-hard.

B) INCORRECT:

Recurrent episodes of thyrotoxicosis alternating with euthyroidism may be seen with painless thyroiditis. Painful thyroiditis is usually a one-time occurrence.

C) INCORRECT:

Thyroid pain can also be seen in acute suppurative thyroiditis or a thyroid abscess, which are both generally accompanied by features of sepsis, leukocytosis, and normal thyroid function. Including these conditions in the differential diagnosis is important: If a bacterial infection is missed, treatment might inappropriately focus on symptom relief with antiinflammatory drugs rather than on the antibiotic and surgical interventions that may be necessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Subacute (painful) thyroiditis is characterized by a prodrome of myalgias and fever, followed by anterior neck pain. Symptoms of thyrotoxicosis secondary to the release of stored thyroid hormone from the inflamed gland are common and can be managed symptomatically with beta-blockers. The thyrotoxic phase is often followed by a hypothyroid phase that can last several months but usually resolves, restoring normal thyroid function.

E) CORRECT:

Subacute (painful) thyroiditis is characterized by a prodrome of myalgias and fever, followed by anterior neck pain. Symptoms of thyrotoxicosis secondary to the release of stored thyroid hormone from the inflamed gland are common and can be managed symptomatically with beta-blockers. The thyrotoxic phase is often followed by a hypothyroid phase that can last several months but usually resolves, restoring normal thyroid function.

Graves disease manifests with thyrotoxicosis, but the goiter is not usually tender. Patients with Graves disease may have spontaneous disease remission, but treatment usually requires antithyroid medications, radioactive iodine, or thyroidectomy.

Key learning point: Initial thyrotoxicosis in subacute thyroiditis is usually followed by 4 to 6 months of hypothyroidism, then restoration of normal thyroid function.

questions.text:
