A 35-year-old man reports unintentional weight loss of 6.8 kg, as well as daily sweats and palpitations, over the past 4 months. He has no significant medical history and takes no medications or supplements. He is a nonsmoker and drinks socially. He notes that his mother takes levothyroxine.
His temperature is 36.7°C, his heart rate is 105 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, and his respiratory rate is 12 breaths per minute. His thyroid is diffusely enlarged, and his deep-tendon reflexes are brisk. His skin is warm and moist. There is no lid lag or exophthalmos. He has a hyperdynamic precordium. There are no signs of congestive heart failure, and his abdominal examination is normal. He has a fine postural tremor with hands outstretched.
Electrocardiography reveals sinus tachycardia without evidence of myocardial ischemia.
His comprehensive metabolic profile and complete blood count are normal. Laboratory testing reveals a thyroid-stimulating hormone level of 0.01 μU/mL (reference range, 0.5–4.7), a free thyroxine level of 3.3 ng/dL (0.8–1.8), and a positive test for thyrotropin-receptor antibodies.
A 24-hour radioactive iodine scan reveals diffuse uptake of 51%.
Which one of the following therapies is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Graves disease is an autoimmune disorder of the thyroid characterized by hyperthyroidism. Symptoms may include palpitations, increased bowel movements, tremors, heat intolerance, weight loss, insomnia, and sweating. Laboratory hallmarks are a suppressed thyroid-stimulating hormone level and elevated peripheral thyroid hormone levels, often with higher triiodothyronine levels than thyroxine levels. A test for thyrotropin-receptor antibodies is sensitive and specific for Graves disease. A 24-hour radioactive iodine scan often shows diffuse, nonsuppressed homogenous uptake of >10%. Physical examination often reveals sinus tachycardia, goiter, exophthalmos, lid lag, postural tremor, and hyperreflexia.

In contrast to symptomatic hyperthyroidism, the clinical manifestations of thyroid storm include severe hyperpyrexia, seizure, coma, arrhythmias, congestive heart failure, abdominal pain, and unexplained jaundice.

If patients are symptomatic, treatment for Graves disease should be initiated.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial medical therapy for a patient with new-onset Graves disease who has recently experienced unintentional weight loss and who has tachycardia and palpitations is methimazole plus a beta-blocker.

B) INCORRECT:

Thionamides, such as methimazole, block thyroid-hormone synthesis and may have immunomodulatory effects. Therefore, methimazole is generally recommended as first-line treatment for Graves hyperthyroidism. Beta-blockers such as propranolol antagonize the effects of triiodothyronine on the heart and sympathetic nervous system and inhibit the conversion of thyroxine to triiodothyronine. Beta-blockers effectively reduce symptoms such as palpitations, anxiety, and tremor in patients with hyperthyroidism and thus should be combined with thionamide therapy in highly symptomatic patients.

C) INCORRECT:

Propylthiouracil has more adverse effects (including hepatotoxicity) and a shorter half-life than methimazole; therefore, methimazole is generally recommended as first-line treatment for Graves hyperthyroidism. Beta-blockers such as propranolol effectively reduce symptoms such as palpitations, anxiety, and tremor in patients with hyperthyroidism and thus should be combined with thionamide therapy in highly symptomatic patients.

D) INCORRECT:

Beta-blockers such as propranolol effectively reduce symptoms such as palpitations, anxiety, and tremor in patients with hyperthyroidism and thus should be combined with thionamide therapy in highly symptomatic patients. Although many clinicians use propranolol for hyperthyroid patients, cardioselective beta-blockers such as atenolol and metoprolol are also effective and can be dosed less frequently than propranolol.

E) INCORRECT:

Propylthiouracil also inhibits conversion of thyroxine to triiodothyronine, but it has more adverse effects (including hepatotoxicity) and a shorter half-life than methimazole; propylthiouracil must be taken at least three times daily to effectively block hormone synthesis, whereas methimazole can be dosed once or twice daily. Therefore, methimazole is generally recommended as first-line treatment for Graves hyperthyroidism.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents with plaques on her shins. She also notes hyperhidrosis, weight loss, and irritability. She is not taking any medications.
Her heart rate is 105 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination confirms the presence of extensive woody plaques on her anterolateral shins (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ovarian cystadenocarcinoma can lead to peripheral edema from venous compression in the pelvis, but it would not typically be associated with hyperhidrosis or dermal plaques.

B) INCORRECT:

Necrobiosis lipoidica is a granulomatous disorder characterized by orange-yellow to brown plaques, overlying telangiectasia, and eventual atrophy. It has been associated with type 2 diabetes.

C) CORRECT:

Hyperthyroidism can manifest as symptoms of irritability, difficulty sleeping, heat intolerance, and menstrual irregularities. Pretibial myxedema (thyroid dermopathy) and thyroid acropachy (clubbing) are rare findings, occurring in <1% of patients, but can be important clues to the presence of Graves disease. Pretibial myxedema is characterized by nonpitting, woody plaques, most often on the shins. It typically occurs in patients who have ophthalmopathy.

Key learning point: In a patient with irritability, hyperhidrosis, and indurated plaques on her shins, the most likely diagnosis is pretibial myxedema in the setting of Graves disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Acromegaly can cause hyperhidrosis and other symptoms, but it is not associated with the formation of plaques on the shins.

E) INCORRECT:

Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis is a small-to-medium vasculitis that manifests as palpable purpura, often of the legs. It has been associated with hepatitis C virus infection and autoimmune diseases.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old primigravida woman at 10 weeks' gestation reports palpitations, nausea, vomiting, loose stools, and 1.4 kg of weight loss.
On examination, she is anxious and has a heart rate of 108 beats per minute. Her blood pressure is 137/80 mm Hg. Her thyroid gland, which is diffusely and symmetrically enlarged to twice the normal size, is firm and nontender. A thyroid bruit is audible. She has an eyelid lag but no proptosis or periorbital edema.
Her serum thyroid-stimulating hormone level is 0.02 μU/mL (reference range, 0.5–4.7), and her free thyroxine level is 4.1 ng/dL (0.8–1.8).
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Offer iodine 131 thyroid ablation in the second trimester
Recheck thyroid levels 2 weeks after initiating daily use of saturated-solution potassium iodide
Titrate methimazole until the thyroid-stimulating hormone level rises to the low-normal range
Initiate prednisone and continue that treatment until the second trimester
Titrate propylthiouracil until the free thyroxine level drops to the high-normal range

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Iodine 131 is contraindicated in pregnant women because of the risk for fetal thyroid ablation. Women should avoid becoming pregnant for at least 4 months after treatment with iodine 131.

B) INCORRECT:

Potassium iodide is not recommended because it may result in fetal thyroid dysfunction and goiter.

C) INCORRECT:

Whether propylthiouracil or methimazole is safer for managing hyperthyroidism in pregnant women is not clear. Propylthiouracil was previously considered safer than methimazole (which has been associated with aplasia cutis), but this assumption has become controversial. Recent guidelines recommend propylthiouracil in the first trimester and methimazole in the second and third trimesters.

D) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids, such as prednisone, are not indicated for pregnant women with hyperthyroidism and appear to have a minimal effect on thyroid hormone levels.

E) CORRECT:

Among the potential causes of hyperthyroidism in pregnant women are Graves disease, an autonomous thyroid nodule, and thyroiditis. The findings of a goiter and a thyroid bruit are most consistent with Graves disease.

Whether propylthiouracil or methimazole is safer for managing hyperthyroidism in pregnant women is not clear. Propylthiouracil was previously considered safer than methimazole (which has been associated with aplasia cutis), but this assumption has become controversial. Recent guidelines recommend propylthiouracil in the first trimester and methimazole in the second and third trimesters. The goal of therapy is to keep the patient’s free thyroxine level in the high-normal range using the lowest possible dose of a thionamide. Beta-blockers may be used during pregnancy to ameliorate the symptoms of thyrotoxicosis until thionamide therapy reduces thyroid hormone levels.

Key learning point: Antithyroid medications should be titrated during pregnancy until the patient’s free thyroxine level is in the high-normal range, using the lowest possible dose of a thionamide.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman reports that during the past 5 months, she has lost 3 kg of body weight unintentionally and has been experiencing palpitations, anxiety, and heat intolerance. She reports no recent iodine exposure and is not pregnant.
On examination, her heart rate is 110 beats per minute, her blood pressure is 142/64 mm Hg, and her temperature is 37.4°C. She is found to have lid lag with a prominent stare, hyperreflexia, and resting tremor. Her neck examination shows a thyroid gland that is easily palpable; it is slightly enlarged, symmetric with no nodules, and nontender. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable.
Her thyroid-stimulating hormone level is undetectable, and her free thyroxine level is 3.25 ng/dL (reference range, (0.8–1.8). Her thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin index is 1.3 (≤1.3). A pregnancy test is negative.
Which one of the following next steps in evaluation is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thyroid peroxidase antibodies are nonspecific and may be elevated in Graves disease, Hashimoto thyroiditis, or a range of other autoimmune conditions. Thus, measurement of these antibodies would not help narrow the differential diagnosis of thyrotoxicosis.

B) INCORRECT:

TSH-producing pituitary adenomas are very rare and would be associated with elevated (or inappropriately normal) TSH and free thyroxine levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Thyroid ultrasound does not generally contribute to the differential diagnosis of thyrotoxicosis. In situations where radioactive iodine is contraindicated (e.g., pregnancy), ultrasound with Doppler may be helpful to confirm thyroid hypervascularity as is seen in Graves disease. If the thyroid nodule does not take up iodine on the iodine-123 radionuclide scan, then a thyroid ultrasound to assess for thyroid cancer would be indicated, possibly with biopsy, depending on the ultrasound characteristics of the nodule.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has clear clinical findings of thyrotoxicosis (tachycardia, tremor, hyperreflexia) with confirmatory thyroid function testing, but the underlying etiology is not clear. Graves disease is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism — and in some cases can be diagnosed on the basis of the physical examination (large non-nodular thyroid and new-onset ophthalmopathy) and thyroid function testing. However, in this case, the diagnosis is not obvious. The patient's thyroid is somewhat enlarged, but her eye findings could represent nonspecific changes due to the increased sympathetic tone seen with thyrotoxicosis — and are therefore not diagnostic of Graves ophthalmopathy. She has undergone thyrotropin-receptor antibody (TRAb) testing for Graves disease, but these results were also equivocal.

Two TRAb tests are available: the thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI) test, which this patient underwent, and the thyrotropin-binding inhibitory immunoglobulin (TBII) test. Both have very high specificity and sensitivity for Graves disease, exceeding 97%, but, occasionally, patients will have false-negative results. Studies have shown that newer, third-generation TRAb assays are as effective for the diagnosis of Graves disease as radionuclide scanning with iodine-123 and are more cost-effective.

However, when the diagnosis is unclear (as in this case, where the TRAb testing was negative despite a high clinical suspicion for Graves disease) or atypical features are present, radionuclide scanning with iodine-123 (or alternatively with Tc-99m) is indicated to help differentiate Graves disease from other causes of hyperthyroidism. In Graves disease, iodine uptake would be diffusely increased or inappropriately normal in the setting of suppressed thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). In the hyperthyroid phase of thyroiditis, the uptake would be very low or absent, and in a patient with a single toxic nodule (a hyperfunctioning nodule secreting thyroid hormone), the scan generally shows focal uptake in the adenoma with suppressed uptake in the surrounding and contralateral thyroid tissue. However, hyperthyroidism in children is typically a result of increased synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormone by the thyroid gland.

Key learning point: The best test to perform to determine the etiology of thyrotoxicosis in a patient with negative results on thyrotropin-receptor antibody testing is radionuclide scanning with iodine-123 or Tc-99m.

E) INCORRECT:

The general practice of radionuclide scanning with iodine-123 may be problematic if iodine-induced hyperthyroidism is suspected. A 24-hour urinary iodide concentration can be obtained to assess the degree of iodine exposure. However, there is no evidence of excessive iodine exposure in this case.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department (ED) because he feels like his heart is racing. He has been seen in the ED several times during the past 4 months for palpitations that are becoming more frequent and bothersome. He also says that he has had difficulty concentrating at work, has been sleeping poorly, and often feels overly warm.
He is afebrile and has a normal respiratory rate. His heart rate is 118 beats per minute sitting and 125 beats per minute standing. His blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg sitting and 110/66 mm Hg standing. On physical examination, he is thin but appears well. His precordium is hyperdynamic with a midsystolic click, followed by a late 2/6 systolic murmur heard best at the apex. His skin feels warm and sweaty. A slight tremor is evident when his hands are outstretched.
An electrocardiogram reveals sinus tachycardia.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s sinus tachycardia?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation — sinus tachycardia with a widened pulse pressure, a midsystolic click, a systolic murmur, and warm, sweaty skin — is most consistent with hyperthyroidism.

Typical symptoms of hyperthyroidism include anxiety, hyperactivity, difficulty concentrating, poor sleep, emotional lability, weakness, tremor, palpitations, heat intolerance, increased perspiration, and weight loss despite a normal or increased appetite. Classic physical findings include a symmetrically enlarged, firm, smooth, and nontender thyroid gland; a palpable thrill or audible bruit over the thyroid gland; tachycardia; a wide pulse pressure; a systolic murmur; and a tremor when the arms or tongue are outstretched. Midsystolic clicks are common manifestations of mitral valve prolapse, which is associated with hyperthyroidism. Complete evaluation for this patient would include an electrocardiogram, an echocardiogram, and measurement of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), with measurement of free thyroxine and total triiodothyronine if the TSH is abnormal.

Key learning point: Persistent sinus tachycardia associated with changes in sleep and attention, a midsystolic click, a tremor, and warm, sweaty skin should prompt evaluation for hyperthyroidism.

B) INCORRECT:

Over-the-counter cold medications can cause heart-rate changes, including tachycardia. However, phenylpropanolamine typically causes bradycardia.

C) INCORRECT:

Coxsackie virus type B is a common cause of viral myocarditis. The time course for this patient’s symptoms, spanning months, is not consistent with acute myocarditis as a cause of his tachycardia.

D) INCORRECT:

Postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome can mimic a variety of medical conditions, with manifestations that include inattention, poor sleep, headaches, and fatigue. The hallmark sign, however, is an orthostatic increase in heart rate (≥30 beats per minute), which this patient does not have.

E) INCORRECT:

Although anxiety often causes persistent sinus tachycardia (evident during medical examination) and may also lead to poor sleep and tremulousness, it is not associated with a wide pulse pressure or a murmur; these findings are more concerning for hyperthyroidism.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man is evaluated after he noticed increasing irritability and a 1.8-kg weight loss. He recently developed diarrhea and is not sleeping well. He reports no stressors or changes in his social situation.
He appears tired but is not in acute distress. His temperature is 37.1°C, his heart rate is 100 beats per minute, his respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute, and his blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg. His skin is moist, his pupils are equal and reactive, and his extraocular movements are intact; there are no features of thyroid eye disease. His neck is supple with a palpable, slightly enlarged, nontender thyroid. There is no thyroid bruit. He has brisk reflexes bilaterally. There is no proptosis. The rest of the examination is normal.
Laboratory testing reveals a thyroid-stimulating hormone level of 0.04 μU/mL (reference range, 0.5–4.7) and a free thyroxine level of 2.8 ng/dL (0.8–1.8). The erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein level are both normal.
A thyroid uptake scan shows low uptake of radioiodine.
What is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Pituitary tumor that secretes thyroid-stimulating hormone

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Graves disease, the most common cause of hyperthyroidism, manifests with a low TSH level, but radioiodine uptake is high because the TSH-receptor antibody acts at the TSH receptor to drive iodine into the gland. A goiter is frequently present, and ophthalmopathy (inflammation of the extraocular muscles and orbital tissues that leads to exophthalmos) is sometimes seen.

B) INCORRECT:

Exogenous thyrotoxicosis caused by ingestion of a liothyronine (synthetic T3) supplement is characterized by symptoms of thyrotoxicosis and an elevated triiodothyronine level; however, free thyroxine levels are not typically elevated. Ingestion of exogenous thyroid hormone is associated with a low radioiodine uptake

C) CORRECT:

Irritability and sleep difficulty in a patient with diarrhea and weight loss — along with physical findings of tachycardia, hypertension, palpable thyroid, and brisk reflexes — are consistent with a diagnosis of thyrotoxicosis. Thyrotoxicosis is most often a result of increased synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormone by the thyroid gland but is sometimes a result of thyroid-gland inflammation with release of preformed thyroid hormone.

If the central feedback mechanism is intact, most thyrotoxic states manifest with a low level of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and an elevated level of circulating hormone (thyroxine and triiodothyronine).

Thyroiditis is a self-limiting form of thyrotoxicosis and is generally mild, as in this case. Because there is no TSH or stimulatory TSH-receptor antibody (as in Graves disease) to stimulate iodine uptake into the gland, the radioiodine uptake is low. Subtypes of thyroiditis include Hashimoto thyroiditis, painless sporadic thyroiditis, postpartum thyroiditis, and painful subacute thyroiditis. Inflammatory markers, such as the erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein level, are very elevated in patients with subacute thyroiditis but are often normal or only slightly elevated in patients with other forms of thyroiditis. Antibodies to thyroid peroxidase (TPO) can be elevated in the painless forms of thyroiditis but are highest in Hashimoto thyroiditis. All forms of thyroiditis can lead to enough thyroid destruction to cause hypothyroidism, but permanent hypothyroidism is most likely in Hashimoto and subacute thyroiditis. At its onset, a slight goiter can be seen with thyroiditis. When TPO antibodies are very high, this is sometimes referred to as Hashitoxicosis and typically occurs before a patient develops classic Hashimoto hypothyroidism. Many patients are asymptomatic during this phase of the disease.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of new-onset thyrotoxicosis in a patient without previously known thyroid disease who is found to have low radioiodine uptake on a thyroid scan is thyroiditis.

D) INCORRECT:

An autonomous thyroid nodule causes primary hyperthyroidism but would result in an area of increased radioiodine uptake on thyroid scintigraphy.

E) INCORRECT:

While a TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma would lead to a high free T4 level, it would have a high, rather than a low, TSH level and the radioiodine uptake would be high.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy is evaluated after his mother becomes concerned about his increasing irritability and a 1.8-kg weight loss. He recently developed diarrhea and is not sleeping well. He reports no stressors or changes in his social situation.
He appears tired but is not in acute distress. His temperature is 37.1°C, his heart rate is 100 beats per minute, his respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute, and his blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg. His skin is moist, his pupils are equal and reactive, and his extraocular movements are intact; there are no features of thyroid eye disease. His neck is supple with a palpable, nontender thyroid. There is no thyroid bruit. He has brisk reflexes bilaterally. There is no proptosis. The rest of the examination is normal.
Laboratory testing reveals a thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level of 0.1 μU/mL (reference range, 0.5–4.0) and a free thyroxine level of 5.8 ng/dL (0.59–2.45). The erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein level are both normal.
A thyroid uptake scan shows low uptake of radioiodine.
What is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Irritability and sleep difficulty in an adolescent with diarrhea and weight loss — along with physical findings of tachycardia, hypertension, palpable thyroid, and brisk reflexes — are consistent with a diagnosis of hyperthyroidism. Hyperthyroidism in children is typically a result of increased synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormone by the thyroid gland.

If the central feedback mechanism is intact, most hyperthyroid states manifest with a low level of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and an elevated level of circulating hormone (thyroxine and triiodothyronine).

At its onset, Hashimoto thyroiditis may manifest with a goiter and initially mild hyperthyroidism, as in this case. This is sometimes referred to as Hashitoxicosis and typically occurs before a patient develops classic Hashimoto hypothyroidism. Many patients are asymptomatic during this phase of the disease. Because there is no TSH-receptor antibody stimulating the thyroid gland as in Graves disease, the uptake of radioiodine into the gland is low.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of hyperthyroidism in a child who is found to have low radioiodine uptake on a thyroid scan is thyroiditis.

B) INCORRECT:

Graves disease, the most common cause of hyperthyroidism, manifests with a low TSH level, but radioiodine uptake is high because the TSH-receptor antibody acts at the TSH receptor to drive iodine into the gland. A goiter is frequently present, but ophthalmopathy (inflammation of the extraocular muscles and orbital tissues that leads to exophthalmos) is rarer in children.

C) INCORRECT:

Autonomous thyroid nodules, also called toxic thyroid adenomas, are a rare cause of hyperthyroidism in children. They are typically large and palpable on examination, and the thyroid uptake scan would show localized uptake.

D) INCORRECT:

A TSH-secreting pituitary tumor is rare in children and would manifest with mildly elevated thyroxine and TSH levels; radioiodine uptake would therefore be high.

E) INCORRECT:

Exogenous hyperthyroidism caused by ingestion of a liothyronine (synthetic T3) supplement is characterized by symptoms of hyperthyroidism and an elevated triiodothyronine level; however, free thyroxine levels are not typically elevated. Ingestion of exogenous thyroid hormone is associated with a low radioiodine uptake. A goiter would not be present with exogenous hyperthyroidism, because the TSH level would be suppressed and chronic suppression of TSH would lead to thyroid atrophy.

questions.text:
A 6-day-old male infant is brought in by his mother for evaluation. He was born at 36 weeks' gestation, and his birth weight was 2.36 kg (10th percentile). His mother has a history of Graves disease that has not been symptomatic. She also reports occasional marijuana use during the pregnancy and no use of other drugs.
Since delivery, the infant has been receiving formula every 2 hours without difficulty and has 12 to 14 yellow seedy stools each day. His mother notes that he seems to startle and cry very easily.
His current weight is 2.1 kg (<3rd percentile), his heart rate is 160 beats per minute, his respiratory rate is 28 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 99% while he breathes ambient air. Red reflexes are present. His anterior fontanelle is open but seems small. He has a soft (2/6) flow murmur at the left sternal border. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The liver edge is palpated 1 cm below the right costal margin. Muscle tone is normal to slightly increased, reflexes are brisk bilaterally, and the Moro reflex is exaggerated.
A chest radiograph is normal.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Wet beriberi is caused by thiamine deficiency and manifests with high-output cardiac failure that can include tachycardia, cardiomegaly, pulmonary edema, and cyanosis. This child does not have signs or symptoms of heart failure (poor feeding, diaphoresis, rapid respiratory rate, abnormal heart sounds, hepatomegaly), and his chest radiograph is normal.

B) INCORRECT:

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (21-hydroxylase deficiency) is characterized by weight loss or poor weight gain, dehydration, and vomiting, but it is not typically accompanied by hyperdefecation or tachycardia. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia can be difficult to recognize in boys because they do not typically have the ambiguous genitalia that is characteristic among girls with the disorder.

C) INCORRECT:

Neonatal abstinence syndrome can manifest with tachycardia, fussiness, diarrhea, and poor weight gain. Children with this syndrome are generally hypertonic, tend to feed poorly, and may present with sweating, sneezing, and nasal stuffiness. In this case, the maternal history is negative for drug use other than marijuana, and the child has adequate intake. Several of the signs of abstinence are not present and would not be expected in the infant of a mother who used marijuana.

D) CORRECT:

Neonatal hyperthyroidism is typically secondary to congenital Graves disease and results from transplacental passage of maternal thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins. Clinical manifestations include intrauterine growth slowing, premature birth, warm and moist skin, tachycardia, hepatosplenomegaly, goiter, eyelid lag and/or exophthalmia, a small anterior fontanelle, advanced bone age, and poor weight gain despite appropriate intake or hyperphagia. The risk for neonatal Graves disease among children of women with Graves disease is approximately 2%. Neonatal Graves disease is typically treated with antithyroid drugs for several weeks until the maternal antibodies disappear from the infant’s circulation.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of tachycardia, hyperdefecation, and poor weight gain despite adequate formula feeding in a jittery neonate born to a mother with a history of marijuana use and Graves disease is neonatal hyperthyroidism secondary to congenital Graves disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Congenital cytomegalovirus infections generally manifest with rash, low birth weight, small head size, retinitis, and seizures but not tachycardia or hyperdefecation.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy presents to the emergency department (ED) because he feels like his heart is racing. He has been seen in the ED several times during the past 4 months for palpitations that are becoming more frequent and bothersome. He also says that he has had difficulty paying attention in school lately, has been sleeping poorly, and often feels overly warm.
He is afebrile and has a normal respiratory rate. His heart rate is 118 beats per minute sitting and 125 beats per minute standing. His blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg sitting and 110/66 mm Hg standing. On physical examination, he is thin but appears well. His precordium is hyperdynamic with a midsystolic click, followed by a late 2/6 systolic murmur heard best at the apex. His skin feels warm and sweaty. A slight tremor is evident when his hands are outstretched.
An electrocardiogram reveals sinus tachycardia.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s sinus tachycardia?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation — sinus tachycardia with a widened pulse pressure, a midsystolic click, a systolic murmur, and warm, sweaty skin — is most consistent with hyperthyroidism.

Typical symptoms of hyperthyroidism include anxiety, hyperactivity, difficulty concentrating, poor sleep, emotional lability, weakness, tremor, palpitations, heat intolerance, increased perspiration, and weight loss despite a normal or increased appetite. Classic physical findings include a symmetrically enlarged, firm, smooth, and nontender thyroid gland; a palpable thrill or audible bruit over the thyroid gland; tachycardia; a wide pulse pressure; a systolic murmur; and a tremor when the arms or tongue are outstretched. Midsystolic clicks are common manifestations of mitral valve prolapse, which is associated with hyperthyroidism. Complete evaluation for this patient would include an electrocardiogram, an echocardiogram, and measurement of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), with measurement of free thyroxine and total triiodothyronine if the TSH is abnormal.

Key learning point: Persistent sinus tachycardia associated with changes in sleep and attention, a midsystolic click, a tremor, and warm, sweaty skin should prompt evaluation for hyperthyroidism.

B) INCORRECT:

Coxsackie virus type B is a common cause of viral myocarditis. The time course for this patient’s symptoms, spanning months, is not consistent with acute myocarditis as a cause of his tachycardia.

C) INCORRECT:

Although anxiety often causes persistent sinus tachycardia (evident during medical examination) and may also lead to poor sleep and tremulousness, it is not associated with a wide pulse pressure or a murmur.

D) INCORRECT:

Postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome can mimic a variety of medical conditions, with manifestations that include inattention, poor sleep, headaches, and fatigue. The hallmark sign, however, is an orthostatic increase in heart rate (≥30 beats per minute), which this patient does not have.

E) INCORRECT:

Over-the-counter cold medications can cause heart-rate changes, including tachycardia. However, phenylpropanolamine is a decongestant that typically causes bradycardia.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl with no significant medical history presents to the emergency department (ED) after a syncopal episode at school. She was playing basketball in gym class when she began to feel dizzy and lost consciousness for one minute. On review of systems, she reports tremors, palpitations, and heat intolerance with increased sweating during the past 4 weeks. She has also had blurry vision.
On arrival to the ED, she has a temperature of 37.3°C, a blood pressure of 140/60 mm Hg, a heart rate of 130 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. She has a symmetrically enlarged thyroid gland without nodules, and eye examination reveals proptosis with lid lag.
Laboratory testing reveals a thyroid-stimulating hormone level of 0.01 μU/mL (reference range, 0.5–4.0), a free thyroxine level of 3.5 ng/dL (0.54–2.23), and a total triiodothyronine level of 312 ng/dL (80–210). A pregnancy test is negative.
What is the most appropriate next test to determine the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Brain MRI may be pursued in patients with central hypothyroidism or if there is concern for an adenoma producing thyroid-stimulating hormone, but MRI has no role in the evaluation of hyperthyroidism.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has clinical and biochemical evidence of hyperthyroidism. Graves disease is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism in pediatric patients, and the physical examination findings of goiter and proptosis are consistent with this diagnosis. Proptosis is specific to Graves disease and is not found in other causes of hyperthyroidism.

The diagnosis of Graves disease can be confirmed with measurement of thyrotropin-receptor antibodies (TRAbs), which have >97% sensitivity and specificity for Graves disease. If TRAb levels are negative or equivocal and Graves disease is suspected, radionuclide scanning with iodine-123 can be used for diagnosis, but this is not the first-line diagnostic test given its cost and limited availability. In addition, TRAb levels may be helpful in predicting the course of the disease and monitoring for remission and recurrence.

Key learning point: The best initial test to evaluate for Graves disease in a patient with clinical and biochemical hyperthyroidism is measurement of thyrotropin-receptor antibodies.

C) INCORRECT:

Measurement of reverse triiodothyronine can be useful in evaluating sick euthyroid syndrome but has no role in patients with hyperthyroidism.

D) INCORRECT:

Measurement of thyrotropin-releasing hormone, which is made in the hypothalamus, has limited clinical utility and is not included in the evaluation of hyperthyroidism.

E) INCORRECT:

Thyroid ultrasound is indicated in a patient with a palpable nodule or an asymmetric thyroid gland, which this patient does not have. This test can also be useful for distinguishing destructive thyroiditis from Graves disease but is not the best initial test to confirm Graves disease.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl reports that during the past 5 months, she has lost 3 kg of body weight unintentionally and has been experiencing palpitations, anxiety, and heat intolerance. She denies any recent iodine exposure and is not pregnant.
On examination, her heart rate is 110 beats per minute, her blood pressure is 142/64 mm Hg, and her temperature is 37.4°C. She is found to have lid lag with a prominent stare, hyperreflexia, and resting tremor. Her neck examination shows a thyroid gland that is easily palpable; it is slightly enlarged, symmetric with no nodules, and nontender. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable.
Her thyroid-stimulating hormone level is undetectable, and her free thyroxine level is 3.25 ng/dL (reference range, 0.59–2.45). Her thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin index is 1.3 (≤1.3). A pregnancy test is negative.
Which one of the following next steps in evaluation is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thyroid peroxidase antibodies are nonspecific and may be elevated in Graves disease, Hashimoto thyroiditis, or a range of other autoimmune conditions. Thus, measurement of these antibodies would not help narrow the differential diagnosis of thyrotoxicosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Thyroid ultrasound does not generally contribute to the differential diagnosis of thyrotoxicosis. In situations where radioactive iodine is contraindicated (e.g., pregnancy), ultrasound with Doppler may be helpful to confirm thyroid hypervascularity as is seen in Graves disease. If the thyroid nodule does not take up iodine on the iodine-123 radionuclide scan, then a thyroid ultrasound to assess for thyroid cancer would be indicated, possibly with biopsy, depending on the ultrasound characteristics of the nodule.

C) INCORRECT:

The general practice of radionuclide scanning with iodine-123 may be problematic if iodine-induced hyperthyroidism is suspected. A 24-hour urinary iodide concentration can be obtained to assess the degree of iodine exposure. However, there is no evidence of excessive iodine exposure in this case, so radionuclide scanning with iodine-123 is the most reasonable next step.

D) INCORRECT:

TSH-producing pituitary adenomas are very rare and would be associated with elevated (or inappropriately normal) TSH and free thyroxine levels.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has clear clinical findings of thyrotoxicosis (tachycardia, tremor, hyperreflexia) with confirmatory thyroid function testing, but the underlying etiology is not clear. Graves disease is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism — and in some cases can be diagnosed on the basis of the physical examination (large non-nodular thyroid and new-onset ophthalmopathy) and thyroid function testing. However, in this case, the diagnosis is not obvious. The patient's thyroid is somewhat enlarged, but her eye findings could represent nonspecific changes due to the increased sympathetic tone seen with thyrotoxicosis — and are therefore not diagnostic of Graves ophthalmopathy. She has undergone thyrotropin-receptor antibody (TRAb) testing for Graves disease, but these results were also equivocal.

Two TRAb tests are available: the thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI) test, which this patient underwent, and the thyrotropin-binding inhibitory immunoglobulin (TBII) test. Both have very high specificity and sensitivity for Graves disease, exceeding 97%, but, occasionally, patients will have false-negative results. Studies have shown that newer, third-generation TRAb assays are as effective for the diagnosis of Graves disease as radionuclide scanning with iodine-123 and are more cost-effective. However, when the diagnosis is unclear (as in this case, where the TRAb testing was negative despite a high clinical suspicion for Graves disease) or atypical features are present, radionuclide scanning with iodine-123 (or alternatively with Tc-99m) is indicated to help differentiate Graves disease from other causes of hyperthyroidism.

In Graves disease, iodine uptake would be diffusely increased or inappropriately normal in the setting of suppressed thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). In the hyperthyroid phase of thyroiditis, the uptake would be very low or absent, and in a patient with a single toxic nodule (a hyperfunctioning nodule secreting thyroid hormone), the scan generally shows focal uptake in the adenoma with suppressed uptake in the surrounding and contralateral thyroid tissue. However, hyperthyroidism in children is typically a result of increased synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormone by the thyroid gland.

The general practice of radionuclide scanning with iodine-123 may be problematic if iodine-induced hyperthyroidism is suspected. A 24-hour urinary iodide concentration can be obtained to assess the degree of iodine exposure. However, there is no evidence of excessive iodine exposure in this case, so radionuclide scanning with iodine-123 is the most reasonable next step. A pregnancy test should be performed in this patient before the radioisotope is administered.

Key learning point: The best test to perform to determine the etiology of thyrotoxicosis is radionuclide scanning with iodine-123 or Tc-99m.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman is brought to the office by her daughter because of a 1-month history of fatigue and a 3.5-kg (7-lb) weight loss. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, hypothyroidism, and Alzheimer's dementia. She lives with her daughter and requires assistance with all of her banking and meal preparation. She does not remember the names of her medications but says she takes them every day. Her pulse is 114/min and blood pressure is 148/101 mm Hg. Physical examination shows warm skin and a tremor. The thyroid gland is not palpable. The serum thyroid stimulating hormone level is undetectable. Histological examination of a thyroid biopsy shows follicular atrophy. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Graves disease is an autoimmune condition in which TSH-receptor autoantibodies lead to overstimulation of the thyroid gland, causing hyperthyroidism and low TSH levels. This patient, however, does not have classic Graves disease features such as exophthalmos, goiter, and/or pretibial myxedema. Furthermore, a thyroid biopsy would show diffuse hyperplasia, not the follicular atrophy seen in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

The combination of hyperthyroidism, an undetectable TSH level, and a thyroid biopsy showing follicular atrophy is most likely secondary to an unintentional exogenous intake of thyroid hormones. This patient has a history of hypothyroidism, for which she likely is taking levothyroxine. The patient's cognitive impairment has most likely led her to mistakenly take extra medication, which has caused her to develop hyperthyroidism.

C) INCORRECT:

Granulomatous thyroiditis is a transient inflammatory condition associated with granuloma formation that can initially cause hyperthyroidism. However, it classically manifests with tender goiter, elevated ESR, and jaw pain. Furthermore, a biopsy would show diffuse granulomatous inflammation, not the follicular atrophy seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased iodine exposure can cause hyperthyroidism and occasionally occurs following treatment with high-dose iodine for autonomous thyroid nodules. However, this is a very rare cause of hyperthyroidism and would normally coincide with the presence of nodules or a goiter. Furthermore, a biopsy would demonstrate tissue hyperplasia, not the follicular atrophy seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Medullary thyroid cancer is a malignant neoplasm of the parafollicular C cells that can cause hyperthyroidism. However, it is an extremely rare cause of hyperthyroidism and would manifest with thyroid nodules or a neck mass. Furthermore, a biopsy would demonstrate parafollicular cell hyperplasia, not the follicular atrophy seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient with mild cognitive impairment presents with unintentional weight loss, warm and moist skin, tachycardia, hypertension, and tremor, which are clinical symptoms of hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department (ED) because he feels like his heart is racing. He has been seen in the ED several times during the past 4 months for palpitations that are becoming more frequent and bothersome. He also says that he has had difficulty concentrating at work, has been sleeping poorly, and often feels overly warm. He is afebrile and has a normal respiratory rate. His heart rate is 118 beats per minute sitting and 125 beats per minute standing. His blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg sitting and 110/66 mm Hg standing. On physical examination, he is thin but appears well. His precordium is hyperdynamic with a midsystolic click, followed by a late 2/6 systolic murmur heard best at the apex. His skin feels warm and sweaty. A slight tremor is evident when his hands are outstretched. An electrocardiogram reveals sinus tachycardia.Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s sinus tachycardia?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation — sinus tachycardia with a widened pulse pressure, a midsystolic click, a systolic murmur, and warm, sweaty skin — is most consistent with hyperthyroidism.

Typical symptoms of hyperthyroidism include anxiety, hyperactivity, difficulty concentrating, poor sleep, emotional lability, weakness, tremor, palpitations, heat intolerance, increased perspiration, and weight loss despite a normal or increased appetite. Classic physical findings include a symmetrically enlarged, firm, smooth, and nontender thyroid gland; a palpable thrill or audible bruit over the thyroid gland; tachycardia; a wide pulse pressure; a systolic murmur; and a tremor when the arms or tongue are outstretched. Midsystolic clicks are common manifestations of mitral valve prolapse, which is associated with hyperthyroidism. Complete evaluation for this patient would include an electrocardiogram, an echocardiogram, and measurement of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), with measurement of free thyroxine and total triiodothyronine if the TSH is abnormal.

Key learning point: Persistent sinus tachycardia associated with changes in sleep and attention, a midsystolic click, a tremor, and warm, sweaty skin should prompt evaluation for hyperthyroidism.

B) INCORRECT:

Over-the-counter cold medications can cause heart-rate changes, including tachycardia. However, phenylpropanolamine typically causes bradycardia.

C) INCORRECT:

Coxsackie virus type B is a common cause of viral myocarditis. The time course for this patient’s symptoms, spanning months, is not consistent with acute myocarditis as a cause of his tachycardia.

D) INCORRECT:

Postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome can mimic a variety of medical conditions, with manifestations that include inattention, poor sleep, headaches, and fatigue. The hallmark sign, however, is an orthostatic increase in heart rate (≥30 beats per minute), which this patient does not have.

E) INCORRECT:

Although anxiety often causes persistent sinus tachycardia (evident during medical examination) and may also lead to poor sleep and tremulousness, it is not associated with a wide pulse pressure or a murmur; these findings are more concerning for hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the office because of intermittent episodes of heart palpitations for 3 weeks. The palpitations are accompanied by chest pain that is sharp and localized to the left 3rd intercostal space. The patient does not smoke. She drinks one to two glasses of wine on the weekends. She appears nervous. Her pulse is 110/min and irregularly irregular, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Examination shows a fine tremor on both hands and digital swelling. There is retraction of the left upper eyelid. A systolic ejection murmur is heard along the right upper sternal border. The extremities are warm, and pulses are 2+ bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Propylthiouracil (PTU) is an antithyroid drug that is used in the medical treatment of hyperthyroidism, which this patient shows signs and symptoms of. However, PTU is usually indicated during the first trimester of pregnancy, whereas methimazole is usually the preferred antithyroid drug for most other cases because of its long duration of action and potency. Moreover, this patient should receive immediate control of her symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

Beta blockers (e.g., propranolol) are indicated for the immediate control of symptoms in patients with hyperthyroidism. This patient with anxiety, tremor, digital swelling, retraction of the eyelid, and irregular heartbeats most likely has hyperthyroidism. Thyroid hormones affect cardiac myocytes directly and also stimulate the proliferation of beta-adrenergic receptors, which can cause cardiac arrhythmias as seen in this patient. Beta blockers decrease the adrenergic tone and therefore reduce tachycardia, control hypertension, improve muscle weakness, tremor, and neuropsychiatric symptoms. Propranolol, in high doses, also decreases the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 by inhibiting the 5'-monodeiodinase enzyme. Thus, this patient should be started on a beta blocker, preferably propranolol, as soon as possible.

C) INCORRECT:

Amiodarone is used in the treatment of ventricular tachycardia and persisting ventricular fibrillation after unsuccessful defibrillation, as well as the long-term treatment of refractory supraventricular arrhythmia (e.g., atrial fibrillation). Because of the high levels of iodine in amiodarone, it may aggravate preexisting thyroid conditions. In this patient, who shows symptoms of supraventricular arrhythmia (palpitations and irregularly irregular pulse) and hyperthyroidism (anxiety, tremor, digital swelling, and retraction of the eyelid), amiodarone should only be considered if other treatment options fail.

D) INCORRECT:

Warfarin is an oral anticoagulant. Patients with atrial fibrillation (AF) are at increased risk of developing thromboembolic complications, which is why long-term anticoagulation is indicated when CHA2DS2-VASc score is ≥ 3 in women or when AF is caused by valvular disease. This patient's CHA2DS2-VASc score is 1 and although she presents with symptoms of AF (irregularly irregular pulse) and a systolic ejection murmur, her murmur is most likely due to the hyperdynamic circulation resulting from the increased adrenergic tone.

E) INCORRECT:

Diltiazem is classified as a class IV antiarrhythmic drug and is used to achieve rate control in patients with atrial fibrillation (AF), which is this patient's most likely arrhythmia. However, another therapeutic option is more commonly used and would also relieve thyrotoxic symptoms, such as tremor and anxiety.
questions.hint: The condition underlying this patient's arrhythmia can also cause heat intolerance, weight loss, and diarrhea.

questions.text: A 33-year-old primigravida woman at 10 weeks' gestation reports palpitations, nausea, vomiting, loose stools, and 1.4 kg of weight loss. On examination, she is anxious and has a heart rate of 108 beats per minute. Her blood pressure is 137/80 mm Hg. Her thyroid gland, which is diffusely and symmetrically enlarged to twice the normal size, is firm and nontender. A thyroid bruit is audible. She has an eyelid lag but no proptosis or periorbital edema. Her serum thyroid-stimulating hormone level is 0.02 μU/mL (reference range, 0.5–4.7), and her free thyroxine level is 4.1 ng/dL (0.8–1.8). Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Offer iodine 131 thyroid ablation in the second trimester
Recheck thyroid levels 2 weeks after initiating daily use of saturated-solution potassium iodide
Titrate methimazole until the thyroid-stimulating hormone level rises to the low-normal range
Initiate prednisone and continue that treatment until the second trimester
Titrate propylthiouracil until the free thyroxine level drops to the high-normal range

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Iodine 131 is contraindicated in pregnant women because of the risk for fetal thyroid ablation. Women should avoid becoming pregnant for at least 4 months after treatment with iodine 131.

B) INCORRECT:

Potassium iodide is not recommended because it may result in fetal thyroid dysfunction and goiter.

C) INCORRECT:

Whether propylthiouracil or methimazole is safer for managing hyperthyroidism in pregnant women is not clear. Propylthiouracil was previously considered safer than methimazole (which has been associated with aplasia cutis), but this assumption has become controversial. Recent guidelines recommend propylthiouracil in the first trimester and methimazole in the second and third trimesters.

D) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids, such as prednisone, are not indicated for pregnant women with hyperthyroidism and appear to have a minimal effect on thyroid hormone levels.

E) CORRECT:

Among the potential causes of hyperthyroidism in pregnant women are Graves disease, an autonomous thyroid nodule, and thyroiditis. The findings of a goiter and a thyroid bruit are most consistent with Graves disease.

Whether propylthiouracil or methimazole is safer for managing hyperthyroidism in pregnant women is not clear. Propylthiouracil was previously considered safer than methimazole (which has been associated with aplasia cutis), but this assumption has become controversial. Recent guidelines recommend propylthiouracil in the first trimester and methimazole in the second and third trimesters. The goal of therapy is to keep the patient’s free thyroxine level in the high-normal range using the lowest possible dose of a thionamide. Beta-blockers may be used during pregnancy to ameliorate the symptoms of thyrotoxicosis until thionamide therapy reduces thyroid hormone levels.

Key learning point: Antithyroid medications should be titrated during pregnancy until the patient’s free thyroxine level is in the high-normal range, using the lowest possible dose of a thionamide.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man reports unintentional weight loss of 6.8 kg, as well as daily sweats and palpitations, over the past 4 months. He notes that his mother takes levothyroxine. His temperature is 36.7°C, his heart rate is 105 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, and his respiratory rate is 12 breaths per minute. His thyroid is diffusely enlarged, and his deep-tendon reflexes are brisk. His skin is warm and moist. There is no lid lag or exophthalmos. He has a hyperdynamic precordium. He has a fine postural tremor with hands outstretched. Electrocardiography reveals sinus tachycardia without evidence of myocardial ischemia. Laboratory testing reveals a thyroid-stimulating hormone level of 0.01 μU/mL (reference range, 0.5–4.7), a free thyroxine level of 3.3 ng/dL (0.8–1.8), and a positive test for thyrotropin-receptor antibodies. A 24-hour radioactive iodine scan reveals diffuse uptake of 51%. Which one of the following therapies is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Graves disease is an autoimmune disorder of the thyroid characterized by hyperthyroidism. Symptoms may include palpitations, increased bowel movements, tremors, heat intolerance, weight loss, insomnia, and sweating. Laboratory hallmarks are a suppressed thyroid-stimulating hormone level and elevated peripheral thyroid hormone levels, often with higher triiodothyronine levels than thyroxine levels. A test for thyrotropin-receptor antibodies is sensitive and specific for Graves disease. A 24-hour radioactive iodine scan often shows diffuse, nonsuppressed homogenous uptake of >10%. Physical examination often reveals sinus tachycardia, goiter, exophthalmos, lid lag, postural tremor, and hyperreflexia.

In contrast to symptomatic hyperthyroidism, the clinical manifestations of thyroid storm include severe hyperpyrexia, seizure, coma, arrhythmias, congestive heart failure, abdominal pain, and unexplained jaundice. If patients are symptomatic, treatment for Graves disease should be initiated.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial medical therapy for a patient with new-onset Graves disease who has recently experienced unintentional weight loss and who has tachycardia and palpitations is methimazole plus a beta-blocker.

B) INCORRECT:

Thionamides, such as methimazole, block thyroid-hormone synthesis and may have immunomodulatory effects. Therefore, methimazole is generally recommended as first-line treatment for Graves hyperthyroidism. Beta-blockers such as propranolol antagonize the effects of triiodothyronine on the heart and sympathetic nervous system and inhibit the conversion of thyroxine to triiodothyronine. Beta-blockers effectively reduce symptoms such as palpitations, anxiety, and tremor in patients with hyperthyroidism and thus should be combined with thionamide therapy in highly symptomatic patients.

C) INCORRECT:

Propylthiouracil has more adverse effects (including hepatotoxicity) and a shorter half-life than methimazole; therefore, methimazole is generally recommended as first-line treatment for Graves hyperthyroidism. Beta-blockers such as propranolol effectively reduce symptoms such as palpitations, anxiety, and tremor in patients with hyperthyroidism and thus should be combined with thionamide therapy in highly symptomatic patients.

D) INCORRECT:

Beta-blockers such as propranolol effectively reduce symptoms such as palpitations, anxiety, and tremor in patients with hyperthyroidism and thus should be combined with thionamide therapy in highly symptomatic patients. Although many clinicians use propranolol for hyperthyroid patients, cardioselective beta-blockers such as atenolol and metoprolol are also effective and can be dosed less frequently than propranolol.

E) INCORRECT:

Propylthiouracil also inhibits conversion of thyroxine to triiodothyronine, but it has more adverse effects (including hepatotoxicity) and a shorter half-life than methimazole; propylthiouracil must be taken at least three times daily to effectively block hormone synthesis, whereas methimazole can be dosed once or twice daily. Therefore, methimazole is generally recommended as first-line treatment for Graves hyperthyroidism.

questions.text:
An 86-year-old woman with a history of coronary artery disease and hypertension is transferred to a rehabilitation facility 5 days after undergoing coronary stenting for symptomatic angina. Her medications are daily aspirin, clopidogrel, and hydrochlorothiazide, with which her hypertension is well controlled. She reports feeling anxious. Pulse is 120/min and blood pressure is 132/85 mm Hg. She is mildly diaphoretic and tremulous. Electrocardiography confirms the presence of sinus tachycardia. Serum studies show:


Thyroid-stimulating hormone
0.05 μU/mL


Free thyroxine
2.9 ng/dL


Thyroid peroxidase antibody

12 IU/mL (N < 20)


Which one of the following conditions is the most likely explanation of the patient’s current presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Struma ovarii results from a rare form of ovarian teratoma that contains thyroid tissue. Thyroid symptoms are rarely the presenting feature. Exposure to radiographic contrast would be unlikely to precipitate symptomatic hyperthyroidism.

B) INCORRECT:

Subacute thyroiditis is associated with recent viral infection, is typically very painful, and would not be expected to be triggered by exposure to contrast medium.

C) INCORRECT:

Riedel thyroiditis is a manifestation of a systemic fibrosis, wherein a progressive fibrosis of the thyroid gland gradually results, most commonly, in hypothyroidism when thyroid function abnormalities occur. It is very rare and has been shown to respond to treatment with glucocorticoids and tamoxifen.

D) INCORRECT:

Hashimoto thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism. Although it can initially manifest with a hyperthyroid phase, this is uncommon and is unlikely to be triggered by iodine exposure. Silent thyroiditis, associated with the release of preformed thyroid hormones and potentially recognized as the thyrotoxic phase of Hashimoto, would likely be associated with an elevated thyroid peroxidase antibody titer.

E) CORRECT:

Patients exposed to a clinically significant amount of iodine-containing contrast medium, such as during this patient’s recent percutaneous coronary intervention, are at risk for contrast-induced thyrotoxicosis if they have underlying thyroid disease, most commonly multinodular goiter with some degree of autonomous thyroid hormone production.

Key learning point: Patients with multinodular goiter or Graves disease, especially older adults or those with dietary iodine deficiency, are at increased risk for thyrotoxicosis after exposure to iodine-containing contrast medium.

questions.text: A previously healthy 25-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 1-month history of palpitations that occur on minimal exertion and sometimes at rest. She feels nervous and irritable most of the time and attributes these feelings to her boyfriend leaving her 2 months ago. Since then she has started exercising more frequently and taking a herbal weight-loss pill, and has lost 6.8 kg (15 lb) of weight. She finds it hard to fall asleep and awakens 1 hour before the alarm goes off each morning. She has been drinking 2 to 3 cups of coffee daily for the past 7 years. Her temperature is 37.4°C (99.4°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 150/70 mm Hg. Examination shows moist palms. Neurologic examination shows a fine resting tremor of the hands. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ with a shortened relaxation phase. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Excessive consumption of stimulants such as caffeine, which is found in coffee and some weight-loss supplements, can cause restlessness, sleep disturbances, tachycardia, hyperreflexia, resting tremor, and palpitations. This patient's weight loss medication may be the source of her symptoms. However, her daily routine of drinking 2–3 cups of coffee is generally regarded as safe for regular consumption. Furthermore, her regular coffee consumption has been a longstanding habit and she is now likely to be well-tolerant to this level of caffeine intake. Therefore, coffee is unlikely to be the cause of her rather recent onset of symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Acute stress disorder is a trauma- and stressor-related disorder. To establish this diagnosis, a patient must meet a wide range of criteria that include arousal symptoms such as the sleep disturbance and irritability seen here, but also and more importantly a history of trauma as well as symptoms of intrusion, negative mood, dissociation, and avoidance. Furthermore, this patient's neurological findings of hyperreflexia and resting tremor suggest a different diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease in which autoantibodies against the thyroid gland lead to the gradual destruction of thyroid tissue. While hyperthyroidism can occasionally be present in acute phases of Hashimoto thyroiditis (Hashitoxicosis), the disease is typically asymptomatic in its early stages and only manifests with hypothyroidism in later stages. Hashimoto thyroiditis is, therefore, not the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms.

D) CORRECT:

Over-the-counter weight-loss supplements and herbal products commonly contain thyroid hormones in amounts high enough to cause thyrotoxicosis. Other groups at high risk for factitious hyperthyroidism are medical personnel who have access to L-thyroxine and use it to lose weight, receive insurance compensation (malingering), or gain attention (Munchausen syndrome/factitious disorder). Goiter, which may be present in some forms of endogenous hyperthyroidism, is absent in patients with exogenous thyrotoxicosis. Low or undetectable thyroglobulin levels indicate that exogenous thyroid hormones have caused the thyroid gland to stop producing endogenous hormones and thus confirm the diagnosis. Treatment includes tapering and ceasing the exogenous hormone intake. Beta blockers can be considered for severely symptomatic patients.

E) INCORRECT:

While patients with generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) may present with irritability, restlessness, and sleep disturbance, patients typically do not show neurological findings such as the increased reflexes seen in this case. Furthermore, GAD is characterized by prolonged and excessive anxiety that is either unspecific or revolves around certain themes (e.g., health, work).
questions.hint: This patient presents with features of hyperthyroidism (palpitations, weight loss, sleep disturbance, irritability, fine tremors, and hyperreflexia). If a thyroid profile were to be done in this patient, the most likely results would be decreased thyroglobulin and TSH levels and increased T3 and T4 levels.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the office for intermittent episodes of sharp chest pain and palpitations. She appears nervous. Her pulse is 115/min and irregularly irregular, and blood pressure is 139/86 mmHg. Examination shows a fine tremor on both hands and digital swelling; the extremities are warm. There is retraction of the right upper eyelid. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amiodarone is used in the treatment of ventricular tachycardia and persisting ventricular fibrillation (VF) after unsuccessful defibrillation, as well as the long-term treatment of refractory supraventricular arrhythmia (atrial fibrillation). Because of the high levels of iodine in amiodarone, it may aggravate pre-existing thyroid conditions. In this patient, who shows symptoms of supraventricular arrhythmia (palpitations and irregularly irregular pulse) and hyperthyroidism (anxiety, tremor, digital swelling, and retraction of the eyelid), amiodarone should only be considered if other treatment options fail.

B) INCORRECT:

Propylthiouracil (PTU) is an antithyroid drug that is used in the medical treatment for hyperthyroidism, of which this patient shows sign and symptoms. However, symptomatic treatment should be started for immediate control of symptoms. Furthermore, while PTU is usually indicated in pregnant patients during the first trimester, methimazole is the preferred antithyroid drug for all other cases because of its long duration of action and potency.

C) INCORRECT:

Warfarin is an oral anticoagulant. Patients with atrial fibrillation (AF) are at increased risk of developing thromboembolic complications, which is why long-term anticoagulation is indicated in women when the CHA2DS2-VASc score is ≥ 3 or when AF is caused by valvular disease. Although this patient has features of AF (irregularly irregular pulse), her CHA2DS2-VASc score is 1 and she has no history of valvular disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Methimazole is an antithyroid drug used in the medical treatment for hyperthyroidism (except during the first trimester of pregnancy), of which this patient shows signs and symptoms. However, symptomatic treatment should be started for immediate control of symptoms.

E) CORRECT:

Propranolol is indicated for the immediate control of symptoms in patients with hyperthyroidism. This patient with anxiety, tremor, warm skin, digital swelling, retraction of the eyelid, and irregular heartbeats most likely has hyperthyroidism. Thyroid hormones affect cardiac myocytes directly and also stimulate proliferation of beta-adrenergic receptors, which can cause cardiac arrhythmias as seen in this patient. Beta blockers decrease the adrenergic tone and therefore improve tachycardia, hypertension, muscle weakness, tremor, and neuropsychiatric symptoms. Propranolol, in high doses, also decreases the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 by inhibiting the 5'-monodeiodinase enzyme.
questions.hint: The condition underlying this patient's arrhythmia causes a state of adrenergic hyperactivity.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the office because of palpitations and insomnia. He reports being well until 7 months ago, when he started a new exercise regimen. Since then, he has noticed intermittent palpitations both at rest and with exertion. He has also noticed a poor sleep pattern but no other issues. He has lost 10 kg of body weight. His pulse is 122/min, blood pressure is 142/61 mm Hg, and his BMI is 32.4 kg/m2. The patient’s palms are diaphoretic, and there is a slight tremor. Laboratory testing shows a thyroid-stimulating hormone level of 0.006 μU/mL and a free thyroxine level of 5.2 ng/dL. Scanning with iodine-123 shows no radiotracer uptake in the region of the thyroid bed. Which one of the following questions is most likely to identify the cause of this patient’s clinically persistent thyrotoxicosis?

choices.text: Have you been taking any supplements to help with weight loss?
Have you been exposed to ionizing radiation?
Do you have a family history of thyroid disease?
Do you have dry, itchy, or swollen eyes?
Do you currently have any discomfort or pain in the neck?

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Ingestion of exogenous thyroid hormone (thyrotoxicosis factitia) results in typical laboratory and clinical features of hyperthyroidism but is associated with a low uptake of radioiodine. Thyroid hormone is occasionally included as an ingredient in weight-loss remedies and hence asking about this would be the most likely way to yield a diagnosis for this patient.

Key learning point: A patient who has several months of persistent thyrotoxicosis and a low uptake of radioiodine can be diagnosed with exogenous hyperthyroidism.

B) INCORRECT:

A history of irradiation to the thyroid is important in the evaluation of a thyroid nodule but of little significance in the evaluation of the thyrotoxic patient.

C) INCORRECT:

A family history of thyroid disease does not reliably discriminate among the various causes of hyperthyroidism.

D) INCORRECT:

Dry, swollen, or itchy eyes can occur with ophthalmic involvement in Graves disease. However, Graves disease is associated with an increased, not decreased, uptake of radioiodine.

E) INCORRECT:

Asking about neck pain is prudent when the suspected diagnosis is subacute thyroiditis. However, when the patient’s symptoms extend beyond 2 months, the diagnosis of subacute thyroiditis is unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient presents with tachycardia, weight loss, sleep disturbance, warm and moist skin, and tremor, which are clinical symptoms of hyperthyroidism.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of anxiety, heat intolerance, unintentional weight loss despite increased appetite, intermittent palpitations, occasional shortness of breath on exertion, and trouble sleeping. Physical examination shows warm, moist skin, a fine resting tremor, and a palpable thyroid gland with a bruit. She refuses radioactive iodine treatment due to concerns about long-term effects and requests immediate symptom relief (see lab results).

Heart rate

112/min (sinus rhythm)



Test
Result
Normal Values



Thyroid-stimulating hormone
< 0.01 mIU/L
0.4 - 5.0 mIU/L


Thyroxine (T4 free)
31 pmol/L
8.5 - 15.2 pmol/L



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Propylthiouracil (PTU) inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis and peripheral conversion of T4 to T3, making it useful in thyroid storm or early pregnancy. However, PTU is not ideal for this patient due to its potential hepatotoxicity and the absence of pregnancy or thyroid storm. Propranolol is preferred for immediate symptom relief.

B) CORRECT:

Propranolol, a non-selective beta blocker, provides rapid symptomatic relief in hyperthyroidism by reducing the effects of excess thyroid hormone on the cardiovascular and nervous systems. It alleviates symptoms such as palpitations, tachycardia, tremors, and anxiety by blocking beta-adrenergic receptors. Additionally, propranolol decreases peripheral conversion of thyroxine (T4) to triiodothyronine (T3), further reducing the hormone's systemic effects. This dual action makes propranolol particularly effective for immediate symptom control in hyperthyroid patients.

Key learning point: In hyperthyroidism, beta-blockers like propranolol are effective for managing symptoms such as palpitations by blocking adrenergic effects.

C) INCORRECT:

Esmolol is an intravenous, short-acting beta-1 selective blocker used in acute settings like thyroid storm or supraventricular tachycardia. Its short duration makes it unsuitable for outpatient management of chronic hyperthyroid symptoms, where a long-acting oral beta-blocker like propranolol is preferred.

D) INCORRECT:

Benzodiazepines address anxiety and insomnia but do not target the underlying hyperadrenergic state in hyperthyroidism. They do not alleviate the cardiovascular symptoms caused by excess thyroid hormones, making them less suitable for comprehensive symptom relief in this context.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman presents with intermittent dizziness and a one-month history of palpitations, heat intolerance, and unintended weight loss of 4 kg. She has a mild tremor in her outstretched hands and warm, moist skin. Vital signs are otherwise stable (see report).

Heart rate
110/min (irregularly irregular)

Electrocardiogram: Atrial fibrillation at 110/min
Which of the following investigations is most appropriate to perform next?

choices.text: Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone and free thyroxine measurement

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serum catecholamine measurement is used for pheochromocytoma evaluation, characterized by episodic symptoms like severe headache and hypertension. The patient's symptoms align more with thyroid hormone excess, not increased catecholamine production.

B) CORRECT:

The patient's symptoms, including weight loss, heat intolerance, palpitations, tremor, and atrial fibrillation, suggest hyperthyroidism. Measuring serum thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and free thyroxine (T4) is essential for diagnosing hyperthyroidism. In primary hyperthyroidism, TSH is typically suppressed due to negative feedback from elevated thyroid hormones, while free T4 is elevated. This evaluation is crucial for confirming thyroid hormone excess and guiding management.

Key learning point: In patients presenting with atrial fibrillation and symptoms suggestive of hyperthyroidism, thyroid function tests are the most appropriate next investigation to assess for hyperthyroidism as a potential underlying cause.

C) INCORRECT:

Transthoracic echocardiography assesses cardiac structure and function, useful in atrial fibrillation cases to evaluate for valvular disease or cardiomyopathy. However, it does not address the suspected thyroid dysfunction causing the patient's symptoms, such as weight loss and heat intolerance.

D) INCORRECT:

24-hour Holter monitoring identifies intermittent arrhythmias, but the patient's ECG already shows atrial fibrillation. The symptoms suggest a systemic cause, likely thyroid-related, rather than an isolated cardiac rhythm disorder.

questions.text: You are seeing a 33-year-old woman, gravida 1, at 10 weeks' gestation who reports palpitations, nausea, vomiting, loose stools, and a 1.4-kg weight loss. On examination, she appears anxious and her heart rate is 108 beats per minute. Her blood pressure is 137/80 mm Hg. Her thyroid gland is diffusely and symmetrically enlarged to twice the normal size, firm, and nontender. A thyroid bruit is present. She has eyelid lag but no proptosis or periorbital edema. Laboratory studies show a thyroid-stimulating hormone level of 0.02 mIU/L (0.34–5.60) and a free thyroxine level of 53 pmol/L (7.0–17.0). Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Initiate prednisone and continue that treatment until the second trimester.
Offer iodine 131 thyroid ablation in the second trimester.
Recheck thyroid levels 2 weeks after initiating daily use of saturated-solution potassium iodide.
Titrate propylthiouracil until the free thyroxine level drops to the high-normal range.
Titrate methimazole until the thyroid-stimulating hormone level rises to the low-normal range.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids, such as prednisone, are not indicated for pregnant women with hyperthyroidism and appear to have a minimal effect on thyroid hormone levels.

B) INCORRECT:

Iodine 131 is contraindicated in pregnant women because of the risk for fetal thyroid ablation.

C) INCORRECT:

Potassium iodide is not recommended because it may result in fetal thyroid dysfunction and goiter.

D) CORRECT:

Among the potential causes of hyperthyroidism in pregnant women are Graves disease, an autonomous thyroid nodule, and thyroiditis. The findings of a goiter and a thyroid bruit are most consistent with Graves disease.

This woman is in her first trimester of pregnancy, where propylthiouracil is regarded as safer for managing hyperthyroidism compared to methimazole, which has been linked to teratogenic effects during organogenesis (e.g., aplasia cutis). The goal of therapy is to keep the patient’s free thyroxine level in the high-normal range using the lowest possible dose of a thionamide. Beta-blockers may be used during pregnancy to ameliorate the symptoms of thyrotoxicosis until thionamide therapy reduces thyroid hormone levels.

Key learning point: Antithyroid medications should be titrated during pregnancy until the patient’s free thyroxine level is in the high-normal range, using the lowest possible dose of a thionamide.

E) INCORRECT:

This woman is in her first trimester of pregnancy. In this period, propylthiouracil is regarded as safer for managing hyperthyroidism compared to methimazole, which has been linked to teratogenic effects during organogenesis (e.g., aplasia cutis).
questions.hint: This woman is in the first trimester of her pregnancy.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to your clinic with palpitations. She appears nervous. Her pulse is 115/min and irregularly irregular, and blood pressure is 139/86 mm Hg. On examination, she has a fine tremor in both hands, digital swelling, and warm extremities. There is retraction of the upper eyelids. Echocardiography performed 6 months ago showed no abnormalities. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Methimazole is an antithyroid drug used in the medical treatment for hyperthyroidism (except during the first trimester of pregnancy), of which this patient shows signs and symptoms. However, symptomatic treatment should be started for immediate control of symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Amiodarone is used in the treatment of ventricular tachycardia and persisting ventricular fibrillation (VF) after unsuccessful defibrillation, as well as the long-term treatment of refractory supraventricular arrhythmia (atrial fibrillation). Because of the high levels of iodine in amiodarone, it may aggravate pre-existing thyroid conditions. In this patient, who shows symptoms of supraventricular arrhythmia (palpitations and irregularly irregular pulse) and hyperthyroidism (anxiety, tremor, digital swelling, and retraction of the eyelid), amiodarone should only be considered if other treatment options fail.

C) CORRECT:

Propranolol is indicated for the immediate control of symptoms in patients with hyperthyroidism. This patient with anxiety, tremor, warm skin, digital swelling, retraction of the eyelid, and irregular heartbeats most likely has hyperthyroidism. Thyroid hormones affect cardiac myocytes directly and also stimulate proliferation of beta-adrenergic receptors, which can cause cardiac arrhythmias as seen in this patient. Beta blockers decrease the adrenergic tone and therefore improve tachycardia, hypertension, muscle weakness, tremor, and neuropsychiatric symptoms. Propranolol, in high doses, also decreases the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 by inhibiting the 5'-monodeiodinase enzyme.

Key learning point: Beta blockers provide rapid relief from the hyperadrenergic symptoms of hyperthyroidism.
